name: Euro Truck Simulator 2
description: Travel across Europe as king of the road, a trucker who delivers important cargo across impressive distances! With dozens of cities to explore from the UK, Belgium, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, and many more, your endurance, skill and speed will all be pushed to their limits.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: Dual core CPU 2.4 GHz Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce GTS 450-class (Intel HD 4000) Hard Drive: 3 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7/8.1/10 64-bit Processor: Quad core CPU 3.0 GHz Memory: 6 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce GTX 760-class (2 GB) Hard Drive: 3 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Much like my sentiments of Farming Simulator 2013, I fell in love with Euro Truck Simulator 2 and I have no idea why. Mundane job simulators are overwhelmingly garbage, but a select few (including ETS2) are surprisingly compelling. There is no way I can think of to describe this game without sounding terribly drab. You’re a truck driver, and are starting your own shipping company. You have to drive according to the law, take rest breaks, buy fuel, pay for upkeep. There is nothing on paper that should be exceptional about this game, yet for what it is, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is disturbingly enjoyable. I recommend everyone to give it a try.
Looked away for a second to answer a text, wracked up about £2000 in car damage fines.   This game has taught me the importance of not texting and driving.  10/10.
Its like driving in real life but in a truck in Europe and not in real life
It's all fun and games until you're asked to deliver ammunition and chlorine from Germany to France.  11/10 would start another world war

Because of age and health issues I was stopped from driving unless I drove a hand adapted vehicle, which I declined. This game puts me again behind the wheel of a vehicle and I have spent in excess of 230 hours playing this simulator, I love this game and hope further expansion DLCs are soon forthcoming, the mods take this game even further, I have included American trucks, military mods and more paint jobs than I thought possible, immersed in the game you actually do feel as though you are on the road, the detail in trucks cities and countryside, and yes the A'holes that should never be allowed a license to drive are in the game, I let the AI know that if you do things to me I will do unto you, and I did, costing me £100s of pounds in repair bills and fines, but the satisfaction you get when you shove that car or truck into a river if one is close by is to much to resist, this game is for all ages, and I think it teaches all how to drive correctly, the young once familiar with driving a simulator like this will have no trouble obtaining a license, and keeping it clean, take your frustrations out on the traffic AI and drive squeaky clean in the real world, I highly recommend this game.
I let my girlfriend have a try at this game, she started growing chest hair.

This is not goat simulator, or grass simulator, or bread simulator, or another 'stupid' simulator. This is truck simulator, so your job is driving a truck, delivering stuff across Europe. So far as a casual gamer, I didn't find it hard to drive these trucks. Though the AI can be ridiculuos stupid.  So.. you started to get a job, using company's truck. Get some money to buy your own truck so you can start building your own empire.. ehh I mean company. And then buy a garage. Buy trucks and hire drivers. Buy garages in every town. Upgrade your garages. Manage your trucks, your drivers and your garages because you're the boss.  Also, I love how the developer works on this game. Not like *ahem* unity stuff.  You will feel bored 'cause of it's repetitiveness. But sometimes, you will back to drive your trucks again. And then bored, and then drive it again, and feel bored again. And again. Overall, 9/10. Recommended for fans of driving games. Sorry for bad english, **** my grammar <3

It may sound silly, but this is one of the most compelling games I've played in the past several years. It's fun, it's gorgeous, it's engaging and it's very well made, with an active community and a proactive developer who continuously patches the thing. This is the game that finally convinced me to get a 360 gamepad, and that alone was worth it, but the game itself is just fun, and relaxing too. One of my favorite moments was driving through Germany listening to a French radio station when 'Blame it on the Boogie' by the Jackson 5 came on. I'd never heard the song before, but loved it, and the mix of that song, the open road and the lovely graphics were just incredible. Totally worth your time, this game is.

Back when I had first discovered ETS2, I played the demo for hours upon hours. Starting one profile after another. Once the Multiplayer Mod was released, a friend of mine decided it might be time to actually purchase the game and see all it really has to offer.   Now, I've been playing ETS2 since roughly November 2013. But I hadn't actually had it on Steam up until March or April. I've been involved with the Multiplayer community from day one, and have put over 400 hours into multiplayer alone. But, that isn't really the topic of discussion.  So, I estimate I've put in about 200 single player hours (90% of which was off the record) and I've got to say, if you enjoy simple, relaxing, and generally stress-free gaming, ETS2 is certainly for you. I can't tell you how much fun I have going from one end of the map to the other, avoiding the sometimes clumsy Artificial Intellegence cars.   I've played around with the Vanilla version, Mods, all the while rounding some of the trickiest turns and windiest roads between Erfurt and Milano. This is, without a doubt, one of the best games I've ever played. It can take roughly two hours to get from one end of the map to another with the speed limiter on. Not to mention it's still being updated. Not too many games that were made even six months ago continue to add on more content, or even just fix little problems or exploits.   I have to give it to SCS on this one. This game is their baby, undoubtably the best game they've ever made. And they treat it as such.   Not to mention the Community. The ETS2 Community is very fond of SCS. And that is for one simple reason: They listen.   SCS listens to the suggestions given to them from within the Community, Unlike most big companies, (Not gonna name any names here... *Cough* EA *Cough*) which seem to only care about the game and it's Community for a short time. While SCS has continued to progress the developement of this game and it's Community. And believe me, guys and girls. We, the Community, notice and appreciate your efforts. So, on behalf of the entire ETS2 Community, I'd like to say Thank you.  The amount of DLC for this game is quite substantial. With the new Cargo Pack update, and a potential Rigid trucks update coming out (Nothing official, just being considered) this is shaping up to be one hell of an amazing game. SCS, you're going places, and I'll be right here when you get there.   I've been playing trucking games since the days of Hard Truck one, so I know what it takes, and what people generally want. And I'd say you've hit the nail on the head. And I know ATS is going to be flatout incredible. Happy Trails, SCS.   Keep in mind, comparing this game to current gen games is not what I intend to do. It's being rated based on it's release date, and it's updates since then.  Physics: 7/10.  Truck model detail: 10/10.  Map size: 10/10.  Texture detail: 9/10 (For it's time and what it is)  Menu layout: 10/10. It's super easy to use, and rather user friendly for new players.  Immersive aspect: 10/10. I can't tell you how many times I've started playing, and forgot I was playing a game for a bit. It's really easy to lose yourself in this game with some good music and a Radio Play or two.  Overall, I have to give this game a 9.8/10. It's fantastic, and certainly worth the money.

The best thing about this game is the experience.   I have not spent a lot of time in Europe, but I feel like I have after driving from Scotland to Hungary. You've probably read all the other reviews here and in publications talk about the experience of just slipping into some kind of 'groove'. You will be cruising down the autobahn with a load of potatoes at 3:00 AM with the radio on to some Dutch station and just lose yourself in that moment, almost as if you can roll down the window and feel the wind blow in. Those moments create immersion in a way few games can and this game will creep up on you with them. When you do make it to Milan with those potatoes you will feel like you've accomplished something.  The experience is the best part about this game, and while it's great I find myself wishing that the whole 'company management' aspect of this game was done just a bit better. It has the bare bones there, you buy trucks, hire guys, buy garages, make money, but I wish it had more depth and strategy than it does. There's enough there to make you care about hitting the road with that load of tractors or upgrading your engine, but it's not quite what it could be to make this a truly killer game.  But what is here, those 'on the road moments', is worth it.

There are titles in the simulation market which can be sold on the novelty factor alone, but tend to be disappointing games. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is not one of them, it is strangely cathartic, engaging and relaxing. Unlike other niche games, there is a smaller barrier to entry and features a simple control scheme for newcomers. There are some reservations such as an infuriating penalty system and a lack of vehicles on major highways but these are outweighed by the positives. Overall, for the fee of 20€, I would highly recommend this driving experience even if it’s not something that would usually be on your radar.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game that simulates the life of a truck driver. Lately the game came with many graphical improvements and physically. You have several options to customize the tractor for free. The big problem with this game is financial. Expansion packs, custom paints and other things like 'Cabin Accessories' cost. The game updates are focusing just for fixing bugs and implementing a single new thing, everything else costs.  To buy the game, the expansions, 2 DLC (High Power Cargo and Cabin Accessories) and all of the paints cost around 89,21€. To buy just the game and the expansions with the 2 DLC it's cost 56,45€. I think is too much for a game like that.

Driving a truck through europe.....snorefest much?  That was my first thought when I got this game and most people I know share that thought. There was a huge hype over the game tho so I gave it a shot......  ...took me ONE tour to hook me up.    Seriously. Whats fun about this game?  Your truck is a big slow brute, almost everything on the road is faster then you, your acceleration is matching a snails and turning takes hours (felt)...WHAT exactly can be fun about it?  For me.....  - its very relaxing to follow the street and be challenged with realistic physics and traffic rules - visuals are AWESOME if you take the time to look around there are so many details  - a skill system enables you to evolve and improve your own driver and build up a trucking company - mostly its about the EXPERIENCE, its not a racer, its not a reaction game....it enabley you to do something most people cannot do in real life ----> commanding 800 horse power at your leasure  I am playing it with keyboard and mouse (for steering and looking around) which works out quite well for me once I adjusted various sensetivities. I seriously consider getting me a steering wheel, camera (to enable me to 'look' around with my head) and pedals for better control tho.  It certainly isnt for everybody. I m just saying you dont know if its your game or not if you dont give it a chance. I 'thought' this would never work for me and here I am....happily trucking away while my wife watches me shaking her head :)

I was never interested in simulators, but this one changed my opinion. I've never driven a vehicle in real life, but Euro Truck Simulator knows that not everybody is skilled driver, so i can change the 'difficulty', aka just press W to go forward and S to slow/go backwards. First 50 hours, i've been driving with a keyboard. Drove about 55 thousand kilometers, then i left the game for a while because it was quite boring. But now i've made a fresh new profile, which is fun to play. Euro Truck Simulator 2 also beats Euro Truck Simulator 1, which was so boring for that money i spent on it (about 40 euro then) by several aspects  1. Graphics - ETS2 has beautiful graphics and good optimalization, so with some time spent, you can make the game playable (My setup is Intel Core 2 Duo and 650GTX for your info)  2. Features - I don't have to park at the end (much better for me, i'm lame at parking correctly, always took me like 15 mins), GPS! You don't have to check the map every 5 seconds, you always carry your GPS which points you to the end of the journey! Also the GPS has ETA time (calculated time when will you arrive), time left to ship the trailer, and other good things  3. AI - Sorry for swearing, but before 1.9, AI was total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Not because cars are flying around, but cars that driven like idiots, made me slow, waiting 5 minutes, blocking, crashing because you're lame and stuff, but after 1.9, the drivers have gotten brains so they arent driving like drugged ♥♥♥♥ers.   10/10 would play again

This game is splendid, the genre of simulation games gets a lot of bad reputation and is generally the laughing stock. Euro Truck Simulator 2 just doesn't care and just became a really good game. If you like driving around, micromanaging your employees, or just like to mess around in simulators it is possible to do so in this.  At first I was skeptic and I bought it on impulse but at the point of writing this I have played more than 50 hours driving around Europe, every country really is a unique experience with a lot of details added to the side of the roads making you feel like you're really there. I thought it wasn't true untill I hit some areas I've been too in my past although sometimes the road was a lot shorter than in real life, it still really felt like I was there, looking around from my truck, in the mountains, over the bridges and through the forests, the view takes your breath away. If you just like traveling, this game really gives a good experience of traveling with a truck.  I really have to mention the roads, they are different everywhere, whereas in the UK you'll find a lot of roundabouts and you drive left, when you cross the pond by ship or train, you get on roads that are really specific to the countries, in the Netherlands for example you have these roads with orange browny sides that are meant for bicycle riders, in Poland you get roads that are a bit broken left and right, they are a straight contrast. Not to forget the different gasstations on the sides of the road, the tollhouses for tollroads, the bordercrossings, they all have a lot of variaty, the cities difer a lot.   The truck handling really feels, when you drive without a trailer it feels like you're weightless, you pull up so fast and you corner so nicely, put a trailer behind it and it is the opposite. Depending on the weight of the trailer, it can be really heavy, trying to get up to speed can be a drag with those weights and trying to race the corners can be a large accident, you really feel like you're heavy when you have a trailer behind you. The things you can transport also make a difference a whole lot of difference, sometimes you transport bottom heavy diggers of 25 tons and you just feel you got a lot of grip in the corners, but then the next time it is sand which is heavier in the center of height, and you go through a corner at a medium pace and you start tipping, you just know right there that the next corner you can't go as fast anymore. The difference between two trucks is also noticable, every truck is different some have a lot of horse power and torque, whereas others have barely any and need to really pull their strength to get up a hill. If you go to a garage to repair your truck you can also upgrade it and customize it, making it even better than before.  The games controls are also good, though lacking controller support, it has support for steeringwheels and joysticks. It for example does support the sticks on my controller but it does not support any of the buttons, though this can be solved with things like xpadder, it would still add a lot to the game if it had native support.  I would definitely recommend it if you enjoy trucking it really has the full experience.

Excellent game some real good mods available glad to see game on steam  Hi  Well i thought it was time to re-visit this review the original review was very brief and written in Jan 2013  Euro truck simulator 2 would have to be one of my favorite games of all time the game now has the following it deserves im glad SCS has hit the big time with this game i got this game as per-order the only per-order i had no issues with my hours are not very well reflected on steam i original had it off steam.  Graphics: Overwhelming good weather its modded and unmodded it gives off realistic feel and they are always improving them which is great to and by far the best graphics in a simulator in my mind but the great thing is they can be turned down so you can play on low end system if you wanted to me i run 3 screens and run graphics at max with no issues. Only thing i feel is missing is skid marks from brake lock up and smoke and skidding sound would be great addition.  Controls: The controls are another great feature and SCS has pretty much taking care of every one from key board and mouse to different brand wheel and pedal combos and every other variety available i currently have a simulator rig which has a Logitech G27 wheel and shifter but i run Fanatec pedals this works well with ETS2 after bit of playing around in the settings to find your comfort Zone but the load cell does make it difficult as it feels like ETS2 does not recognize it.  Game-play: Well the game-play is virtually never ending and running your own company can get very busy especially when you have alot of different drivers working for and trying to maintain there skill points trucks and delivery's plus driving yourself as well i think all in all this is a great concept with plenty of ways to play weather you want to run solo or have team of truckers working with you.  Content: how to explain this with out talking for hours the world is your oyster i guess weather you stick to SCS original game content and use there DLC which are available here on steam or you combine there DLC with the many many mods available through the many fan sites with this only it makes the game feel fresh. With mods please use a test profile as SCS does to offer support for modded games which i understand and agree with i have a test profile and my main profile my main profile is heavily modded and is my same profile from the first day i installed ETS2 which shows if your careful you can have great experience.  Physics: These are very surprising and realistic creating an accurate simulator in your home is not easy but ETS2 gives a very good sim feeling with you play on you sit in sofa or desk chair or sim rig to play you can feel every bump twist and turn with great immersion factor  Overall this is a great game i personally recommend it to any sim fan or truck fan even if its not your normal style of game i recommend trying it out its great fun.  PROS: excellent graphics, excellent controller support, excellent price, lots of content and game-play  CONS: can be difficult to find comfort zone with load cell brake pedal ,no skid marks smoke or skidding sounds

For the first time you play this sim, you'll get in touch quickly with almost everything in normal option. I believe since this is a 'simulator' game, you should go deeper than what factory setting gave you. Try to use gamewheel, force feedback in this game is pretty awesome, you can tell the difference when you have goods in your back that empty trailer, if you don't have one, mouse steering still give you precision and little of the force feedback you want. every truck has it's own 'fingerprint', Volvo feed your hunger for power, rather than majestic (or should I say Mercedes) will give you god touch of driving in the city and hill. ridiculous precision of a one's brand for such simulator. Oh! don't forget to learn ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ braking and engine braking. And make the rain probability slider in option to go about 40%, rain is rarely happen under that mark, and rain is awesome! try to use 'simulator' feature as many as you can, sure it'll bring you joy for fancy truck driving.  I'm not going to whiny about graphics, but since in this game all you have to do is driving, having a good view of landscape and city is a need. Graphics pretty nice, what makes me impress is ETS2 have widely variant of graphic setting. I still can have nice graphic at my GT520M at my laptop (7/10) and a perfect breeze at my desktop GTX660.  Here's a little con you'll find, not that many - sometimes when I go to the left/right, cars from opposite way of me didn't stop even after my truck body is eat up half of the road space. it's a little bit annoying to get -£400 - you cannot set how many hours you want to sleep at the truck stop, sometimes I missed the delivery time for some mission because of this. - mouse steering sucks because you can't move your head without holding RMB.  It's sure a great sim! be warned for addiction and dreaming become a truck driver.

I'll never figure it out and I don't intend to but ETS2 is fun. I don't know why it is. It might be just that it is a very relaxing game as it relieves stress from me when I'm stressed. Maybe it might be that sound of the truck inside of the truck. This game is really fun but all I'm doing is driving a truck with cargo to my destination. Driving with a controller feels really nice and this entire game feels really nice. ETS2 is also moddable but I like to keep this game vanilla because I feel there isn't much wrong with it. The huge open world is really nice, too. The addition of the radio is really nice so I can listen to my own music or music from European radio stations. There is also a management system where you can manage your own company and buy cars for your garage and send drivers out on cargo delivery missions. ETS2 is also very atmosphereic. I feel like I'm actually driving the truck and I don't want to leave. The car AI could be worked on but it works fine most of the time. ETS2 feels very polished for an indie game. And with the announcement of American Truck Simulator, now is an even better reason to pick it up. I recommend playing with headphones on and while listening to some radio stations at a lowish volume. Buy this game if you're looking for a game to play to relieve stress or try out the demo because the demo actually offers quite a bit of content and can keep you busy for a couple hours. I really don't understand the concept of driving a truck being fun but hell if it isn't.

This game took me by surprise. I only purchased this game as it was on sale, and I figured a few extra achievements couldn't hurt right?  Well I have no interest in trucks I find myself playing this game and enjoying it. This game really does do a very good job of being a truck simulator. It is complete with customization options, plenty of DLC if you get bored of the base game, an excellent set of mods (Not from Steam Workshop) can be installed which can further enhance your gameplay experience.  If you are a truck fan, this game is almost certainly a must have. Someone who is a truck fan would absolutely love this game to bits.  If you're not a truck fan, you may, or may not like this game but if you can get it when it is on sale you should try it before mocking it, it actually does what it is designed to do very well.  Although, I'd highly recommend having a music player playing music in the background as the long drives can be a bit daunting without it.  As for its down sides.. I couldn't get the built in radio player to work on Linux at all with MP3 or radio streams as is apparently supported. Not a big issue for me as I just used another media player to have music in the background.  It can also be very resource intensive also so you may need quite a beefy system if you want to wack the graphic settings up.  So to break all this down into a nice pro/cons list:  Pros:  - Very well built simulation game. Does what it says on the tin.  - Has achievements/trading cards for those who may want them.  - Cannot be simply 'beaten' in a few hours like most modern games.  - Has company management features built in allowing you to employ people, buy trucks etc etc etc.  - Trucks can be customized.  - Visually it looks amazing if your system can cope.  - Great modding community that offers many things the base game cannot.  - Multi-platform support  Cons:  - Very resource intensive mostly on the GPU and appears to only be using only 1 CPU core out of 8 on my system  - Framerate can drop in some locations for a few seconds.  - No built in multiplayer (Though can be added via unofficial mods)  - AI traffic can be pretty darn stupid at times and will happily ram you out of your lane if it wants your lane and then charge you for the privilege with a traffic fine.  Hmm, I wanted to list more cons.. but I honestly cannot think of any others. So I'm going to have to say.. yes I recommend this game :-).

Got this game in the Simulator Bundle from Humble Bundle. Saw the game on YouTube and Twitch, and found it very relaxing and quite fun even. The downward spiral had begun. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is just one of those games. One of those really annoying games that we all love. To not like this game is foolish, what is there not to like about it? You can launch it thinking 'I'll do one small job and get off, got homework to do' and at 10pm you are still playing it. Despite all the swearing and crying over all of the times you have crashed and got no money for any of the jobs, it was safe to say that it was time well spent.   Euro Truck Simulator 2 pretty much tells you everything about the game before you play it, but also without really telling you about the game. You are a lorry driver. You drive lorries. You get paid to drive lorries over Europe. It is a very hard game to play. No, it really isn't. Basiclly, drive, deliver your cargo and do it all over again without crashing too much. I repeat - too much. It is a challenge, but one that we all enjoy.   If you are the type that likes really fast paced killing games with blood and gore, then this game is not for you, and if you can't stop killing people, and sit back and enjoy some lovely scenery and driving, then you are not for this game. I think now we have solved that, we can talk about the game. Funny, what have i actually said about the game so far? Do you want to buy it yet? No? I need to try harder, clearly.   10/10 Driving Simulator. Lovely scenery, very well made game, plenty to do, and no time to do it in. I would reccomend this game to anyone that hates lorries and simulators. This is just your type of game.
10/10 Will spend there money on this game.  Haven't played for months, starts up again, gets addicted again.

Huge map of Europe (~2 hours of driving for the longest trip depending on traffic), a large selection of officially branded trucks from all major European truck manufacturers, great graphics, decent AI traffic, a multiplayer mod and endless amounts of high quality, easy to install singleplayer mods.  Look at my playtime in this game... It's one of my favourite games of all time. I play multiplayer mostly using the ETS2MP mod along with thousands of other drivers from around the world, but singleplayer is entirely great also, so whichever you prefer you won't be dissapointed.  I play using a G27 steering wheel, pedals and H-Shifter for maximum immersion, and the game is compatible with Occulus Rift and TrackIR for those that want to go even further!  I can't recommend this simulator enough, get it!  Note: This should be pretty obvious but i'll say it anyway just incase... This game is a simulation of being a truck driver, it isn't a racing sim. Boy racers will be dissapointed.  10/10 - Uber fantastically outstanding!

It takes every ounce of your energy to not take this game at face value, but is imperative to this sublime simulator that you don't. Yes, it is a game about driving trucks. Yes, the hauls get to be long distance. If you're looking for something that keeps you on the edge of your seat, with non-stop action, this is not your game.  However, if you're looking for one of the most true to life, masterfully done, in-depth simulator you've ever sunk your teeth into, you've come to the right place.  I remember joking with my buddies 'LOL who wants to drive truck'. Then a few weeks later, I find myself bored on a Saturday, lo and behold, ETS2 has a demo. I'll give it a shot, what do I have to lose? Just my entire Saturday.  I can't quite put my finger on the exact thing that kept me playing this game for an 8 hour marathon session (I had stand alone before the Steam version). Beautifully, accurately crafted European countryside is a brilliant start. I plopped my trucking company down in London, as I wanted to tour the UK. I buy my first truck, and jump right into my first haul.   Well, the minutes turn into hours, and suddenly I'm the owner of a successful trucking company, myself and 2 employees with my own fleet. As you progress, you level up and can spend points on hauling more dangerous/fragile cargo, longer hauls, more economic hauls (gas/wear and tear), and more. As your employees complete more hauls, they also level up and start bringing in more cheddar.  My only gripe are the punishment systems. I was expecting active traffic police, aka being pulled over for breaking the law. However, the only punishment system is a series of fines. A fine for running a red light, for driving in the wrong lane, for hitting other cars, and traffic cameras (which I'm told are quite common in Europe) for speeding. No lost time in accident investigation or being pulled over, just a popup fine.   The only other punishment system is a damage system to your truck and trailer. Damaging the trailer results in a poor score for the haul, and damaging your truck ends up costing you hefty repair bills. It's also worth mentioning that it seems you get to a point where you make enough money that any punishment is negligible. You make enough money on the haul where a few $500 tickets don't phase you, nor does a small repair.  This game is a perfect getaway when you're looking for a lazy escape. Throw on your favorite tunes, and get to haulin'. ETS2 gets a 4/5.  Apocky+Tawok  www.GuildLeaders.com

Originally written by myself on Metacritic: (contains spoilers)    This has to be the single greatest simulator game every made. It's hard to believe a trucking simulator is as fun as this. I can't believe I'm giving this a 10 out of 10! Anyways; let's start with the pros shall we? So, you start off at the very bottom of the totem pole. You have 0 trucks, you don't have anyone working for you, and you don't have a home garage. (Although you do have a home city that you can pick) You have to do odd little jobs to save up enough money and reputation so that the bank notices you. Once they notice you, you can pull out a loan. With the loan you can buy your own truck and start doing better and more lucrative trucking jobs. Throughout the whole game you are upgrading your stats which allow you to drive farther, haul hazardous material, drive longer distances, haul urgent deliveries, and so on and so forth. Once you gain enough money, you can buy your own garage, and upgrade it. When you have a garage, you can hire others to drive for you. Now, this doesn't mean you can stop driving, but they will start to earn a nice chunk of change. (And you can control what type of cargo they haul)  Now, on top of all of this; this game accepts mods. There are a TON of mods for this game; both user created and professionally created. Some of the mods are horrendous and will crash the game; however some of the mods are extremely useful and make the game a million times more fun. Right now, with my game, I have over 200 different loads I can carry at any given time and I can travel thousands of kilometers. (Then again, everything on mine is maxed out) This is not a game you will beat in one setting, in one day, or even in one week. This is a nice relaxing game to play.  Since I did the pros, I'll do the cons. (Which don't affect my rating because they don't matter much to me) You don't have any damage simulation. Well, you do and you don't. It's a partial simulation. If you damage your truck high enough you will have a tough time driving it as the engine will stall out on you. However, you won't notice any physical damage to your truck. It's all internal and nothing cosmetic will actually show. (Even the AI cars won't show damage when you hit them) Other than that big one, there aren't too many cons. Each person is different though.  I personally recommend this game to anyone into simulation games and anyone who is interested in trucks. You will not be let down.

How I laughed when I first heard about Euro Truck Simulator 2.  'What a silly idea for a game!' I thought, whilst mocking my friend Jack for appreciating the game.  Well, now I'm here eating my own words because this is one of my favourite games of all time. The concept is so small and drab but the execution is excellent and the appeal is abundant. I've always been a fan of Tycoon games and ones that involve money/time management and the general growing of a business. In ETS2, you have to work your way up from a rookie driver doing local deliveries to a pro driver who is trekking across europe in the truck of his choice.  The game is realistic, with great sounds and amazing physics. There are so many customisable options that add great depth. Driving is a joy and it really feels like you have your own job in trucking. But best of all, you're free! This is the PERFECT game to settle down, relax, put some music on and just drive and think. It's truly amazing and that's the appeal I referenced earlier.  So, to conclude, don't judge the book by its cover! Give this gem a go if you see it on sale because I promise you, it will not disappoint! Easily one of my top 5 games ever.

And btw, be prepared for people to look at you strangely once you say you play a truck sim.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a great game, and I have no complaints.   Driving is fun and easy enough, even with a keyboard and mouse, and is as realistic as you make it with multiple levels of complexity, ranging from options suited to a more casual gamer to life-like controls for more serious simulation gamers.  The landscapes you are driving in are beautiful. Their is traffic, weather, and everything you would expect to experience on the road. If my memory serves me correctly, there are also numerous options to control the frequency of rain and things of that nature.  There are numerous upgrades you can obtain for your driver to haul better cargo and make more money, as well as numerous trucks you can buy. You're also able to hire staff, but I have yet to progress that far into the game.  This game is definitely something to try if you have any interest in simulation games. When I was first recommended it I was leery at first, but after playing the game I can safely say it was more than worth it.

I'm sure I'll get bored of this game eventually, but as long as there are 3rd party mods & dev additions, I'll keep on truckin'.

Torino to Edinboro' on a 6x2 Truck. The lull as you slowly drift from on ramp, to motorway and back off again. You pass through cardboard copies of cities, but you don't care cause youre relaxed.  You drive through Germany.  You see a city with the same layout as the previous, AI lorries cut you up at 60MPH and Oncoming traffic spawns just as you've commited yourself to a three car overtake on a long straight.  You curse, slam on the brakes and ease back into the traffic. You get a fine for speeding and being on the wrong side. Thanks Gamelogic.  Before you know it, youre at Dover. You roll off the ferry and are instantly greeted with a 90 Degree turn left, but the turning circle isnt wide enough and there are central reservation barriers on both the exit lane and entry point.  You execute the fabled 324 Point turn, whilst incurring £2,000 in Cargo damage, £1,650 in collision fees and £650 for pressing F7 for roadside assistance.  Edinboro'. You pull into the yard, instantly remember the kerfuffle you had with the 324 point turn and proceed to repeat it for the parking maneuvre.  You conceed defeat and press Enter to auto park.   Then you do it ALL over again, because its so damn relaxing. Did I mention that?

Simulator games!...I love em! As an older gamer in my mid 30's I remember a time when Simulator games were pumped out ten a penny, sure they were mostly 'war machine' sims such as aircraft, tanks or submarines and every system had them from the early 80's wireframe Spectrum 48k efforts right up until the naughties full on 3D rendered apachie v havok (00's) but then with the advent online consoles the quality of sims died off in a big way.  Sure we still had a few knocking special ones knocking around, the silent hunter series and microsofts lacklustre (should have been better) combat flight sim series, but most companies now focused on giving us standard cookie cutter clones of console games year after year.  The past few years have however given us a newlease of sim games some great some not so but all withing their rights beautiful, from the oddly popular farming simulator to the even odder goat simulator were now being treated to some proper PC sim love from gaming studios.  And so eventually we come to Euro Truck Simulator 2 or ETS2 to its fans.  Gamers can now live out their dreams as an EU based trucker, buy a truck, pick a job, drive for miles across international borders while avoiding speeding tickets and dodging crap motorway drivers and dodgy AI (since launch AI is vastly improved), its that simple, thats all their basically is to it.  The games engine isnt the best looking by far but its nice enough to look at for hours on end and trust me, you will look at it for hours on end, and the community have taken to the game nicely so theres lots of modding available, from new trucks and trailers, updated true to life road markings and signs for respective countries, a working radio station mod and even an ad hoc multiplayer mode that actually works.  The game plays well, the trucks handle nicely and theres a nice progression system that allows you to form a fleet of trucks of your own and send out AI drivers to complete jobs, theres a good chunk of customisability to your trucks from new paint jobs to lights, wheels, engines ect.  This all may sound pretty boring and in reality it should be, and yet it isnt, its somehow compelling and extremly satisfying as your make sure you slow down for the speed cameras on the M6 en route to Manchester to ensure you dont get a ticket as you run against the clock to get your load of supermarket goods delivered on time..  It has that fully engaging 'SIM-iness' that all great Sims have, its not ultra realistic as Sims go but it has enough that you feel engaged and has enough addictive quality that keeps you playing and coming back..  So...here I go again, Bacon butty in one hand and travel FM on the virtual radio and a load of concrete pipes that need to be delivered to luxemburg.

I know I have very low hours on this game, I admit I previously pirated it but thanks to the recent sales I got a good deal on it. In general I probably have racked around 100 hours on this game.   This game is really interesting to me. Usually people like games similar to GTA or Need For Speed, which I do like as well, but I also like simulators, like this one. They can really teach you how a lot of the things work, and how to properly drive, check your mirrors, etc.. The tasks are pretty simple. Choose a quick job, drive from point A to B. Along the way you may run crash, run out of fuel, or you may just end up with a traffic ticket. You are able to create your own company, but you don't really have the necessary funds from the beginning of the game in order to buy a truck, a garage, or hire workers. So in all reality, you have to grind out all of the quick jobs in order to even get to that point. Time consuming, sure, but along the way it becomes a second nature to you.  Customization for trucks is great. I believe there are paint job DLCs, which I find to be really nice! Makes your truck stand out from the others and be something unique. You can change basically anything on your truck, from the engine to the transmission, and even the cosmetic stuff, like mirrors, wheels, and much more. Lots of reputable truck manufactuers are present in the game, such as Scania, Volvo, Mercedes-Benz, and many others. The choices are great. Trailers have a good amount of variety as well, and there are a lot of weight differences in them as well.. which is very important.  I would honestly give this game a 8/10. Since it's a huge open world game, a lot of the cities look very similar. I'm sure it's necessary to due that to make it run smoothly and to keep everything working properly. I'm really excited and interested to see what else will be added to this game.. I'd also like to add that the creators of ETS2 are going to release American Truck Simulator next month (at the time this is being written) so that is also something else to keep an eye out for.

'When the seagulls follow the trawler it's because they think sardines will be thrown into the sea.' ~ Hillary Clinton    It's one of them quiet days again. Chillin' in your methlab office, countin' your daily income. Your people downstairs are cookin'. Your boy Jaykwon standin' by the door with a shotgun. Nothin' happens.  But then, the hell breaks loose.  'LAPD, FREEZE MOTHAFUKKAS!' Shieee, man muthafukkin 5-0 stormin your joint. Your guys grab their pieces and start firing at the police. Gunshots all over the place. First few cops get shot but unfortunately your guys are goin' down cuz shieee, they ain't nuthin' more than a bunch of niqqaz, nahmean?   *BAM BAM*   a cop breaches your door and gets inside aiming at you but your boy Jaykwon caps his ♥♥♥ and wounds a guy who followed him. Wounded cop drops his MP5 but draws his sidearm and guns your boy Jaykwon down. You pull your .44 from the drawer and commit 187 on that fukker. ♥♥♥♥♥ is goin' down so you use the zipline and roll down to the hidden garage where you hid your dirtbike and make a run for it.   *KABLAM*   the charges that you planted for this exact situation go off, blasting all the pigs inside. You reach your emergency plane and fly to Argentina where you live, disguised as a TV repairman until one day you get shot by your own son whom you abandoned 30 years ago.  Now, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is nothing like that.  Basically this is a driving RPG. You start as a low grade G with no truck, no rep, no woman, no money, no nuthin' and then you drive. And you drive long and hard until you get money. Then you invest that money. And, if you're lucky, one day instead of working for the money, money will work for you. (Well, you could get a loan from the bank but not only the jewish bankers will penetrate your goy butt but it's also more fun to earn the money yourself).  Now I know what you guys are sayin 'Niqqa, how is that fun? U high?' Well for some reason it is fun. Routes look pretty nice and kinda believeable, graphics are aight, trucks and their cockpits look good, you can install mods if you wish, you can listen to actual radio stations from all across the Europe n ♥♥♥♥♥.  I said that it's an RPG because, except of fines, there is no punishment for not following the rules, speeding, ignoring the red lights and ♥♥♥♥♥. You can't really interact with the drivers you hire, business management is rather simplistic (I hire only blonde girls without even looking at their stats and i'm doing just fine), and the only place where you can see your empire grow are the charts. But the point of the game lays in the role playing. Using your blinkers, watching your speed, minding the trailer while taking narrow turns, taking satisfaction from buying new trucks, hiring new drivers and watching them making money for you. I would hardly call this a 'simulator' but it does a splendid job being an RPG.  There are some downsides too like:  - The cities look aight but they are very small with just some landmarks visible in the distance. - There are no roadside ladies of the night in a game about   driving trucks   (which is especially unrealistic for eastern Europe). - Streets in the cities look empty in general. - Even if you choose to be a black character at the start, your in-game model is a white dude. Racist. - You can't get off your truck to beat the ♥♥♥♥♥ out of AI drivers and I would really, really love that feature. - Some regions, in my opinion, are not as well made as other.  I would reccommend using a steering wheel or a pad, but the game plays surprisingly well with mouse + keyboard. I would also strongly reccomend getting the 'Going East' DLC    which in my opinion should be free but watchu gonna do? Money talks I guess.     Overall, it's an alright game, definitely worth trying.                         THE FUKK YOU LOOKIN AT, HOMEBOY? GO AND BUY THIS GAME   NOW  , SHIEEEEE...

I don't care about trucks in real life or (driving) cars in general, but this game is real fun, in large part because of its realistic feel. It will let you get in touch with how it feels to be a truck driver - at least I guess.  The following experience let me take the time to write this review:  Just accomplished my trainings contract - not a big deal.  Then I was free to pick my first 'real' contract myself. I drove my truck safe and sound out of the parking lot right to the freeway. I concentrated on driving well, keeping on track, making no mistakes and - for christ's sake - having no car accident, because the costs will be substracted from your contract money and damaging your truck or cargo will be bad as well. So I drove carefully and had a close look on the street.  When i looked back to my GPS navigation system I realized i had missed the exit ramp. 'F***!' tried to be cool and looked for the next possible even though not legal way to turn around and get back on track in time - because contracts are time bound. I reversed and *bang*! First crash - 400€ substracted from my contract. -.- I didn't try to reverse and turn around anymore but rather looked for a legal way to turn and get back on track safely. I took the next exit, turned my truck, got back on track, but then a car drove into my truck. Technically not my fault - although to be honest it was my fault - so no 400€ substraction. Thank god! But wait... I checked my cargo and truck damage status and realized... my cargo has been damaged by 1% -.- 'All right then, f*** it!' I thought to myself. I pulled on my ingame radio (game let you search and find real internet radio), got myself a cold beer (not ingame) and pretended to be king of the street from then on - no matter the costs!

Where to start. Well, I enjoy SIM games (already play Football Manager and Roller Coaster Tycoon 3) and I enjoy trucks, so when I saw Euro Truck SIM 2 and saw the clips of the game, I thought I'd give it a try, especially when I saw it on sale at under $4 so I thought 'why not?'. Glad I didn't pass it up as the game is superb and is HIGHLY addictive. I've had the game since Thursday now and I've already put in a good amount of hours.  The game is massive. You start off as a driver for hire in a city of your choosing, and you choose jobs to build up money (or just take out a bank loan if you're impatient) to get your own truck to start up your own business. You can choose from DAF, Scania, Iveco, Volvo, and more, for your trucks, you can hire drivers, buy more trucks, buy other depots...all the things you can do in a real life truck business you can do in this game.  The actual driving part of the game is VERY realistic and the game does a fantastic job of making you feel like you're driving a truck. You drive at night, through the day, in the rain, when it's sunny, have to take a break every 10 hours or so....honestly, it's very realistic to real life trucking.  I cannot think of a negative thing to say about this game, so if you love trucks and you love SIM games then this HAS to be on your list. You will not regret it.
I think if you have your friends with you, and you really drive a convoy 15/10!

I find it amusing to see so many people saying they are surprised at how enjoyable this game is. It was the same reaction I had in the 80s when I played Truckin' on the Intellivision, or Payload for the MSX system for the first time. Of course, they are ancient games, but the concept is essentially the same.  So don't think there's something 'wrong' with you for enjoying such games.  The fact is that trucking simulation has big entertainment potential, and I am glad to see it being explored on the Euro Truck Simulator series. This is a solid game.  Plus, I went to Germany for the first time a few months ago, and while there, as I was riding with someone else I couldn't help but look around and smile at how 'familiar' the roads and the traffic flow seemed.  I think that says a lot about how realistic this game is.

I want to be very clear; I hate myself for buying this game. When I mean I hate myself, I mean that I have a very deep and real sense of self loathing for even having considered buying the game, and then parted with actual money with which to play the game - that is to say, this was not a prank gift. I hate myself for wanting to play the game, and I ESPECIALLY hate myself for enjoying the game when I'm driving along a European highway to the dulcet tones of some random radio present on magic.  That said...There's a beauty about this game; it's actually one of the better driving sims out there on the pc, and if you have a higher end PC...You're going to enjoy the graphics somewhat, and even possibly recognise some of the landmarks of the cities you visit. My only regret is that I have no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ murdering add on pack.  Upon further playing, I realise that there are more problems with this game - as a truck driver, I want to experience the COMPLETE sense of what it is to be a trucker; I want to be french, and cause roadblocks because I can. I want to be a dodgy romanian trucker, and help illegal immigrants enter the UK via one of the convenient docks and/or eurotunnel, and unfortunately - Eurotruck simulator does not allow me to do this. Maybe this is something you can add in the third installment, developers?

Surprisingly addictive (played a non-steam version for a couple of days, months ago before purchasing on Steam, so actual hours played is alot more), making deliveries, the excitement of buying own truck, custom painting your truck (loads of mods out there for custom paint jobs), upgrading your garage and hiring more drivers for your tuck empire. Saying that, after while, does start getting abit boring, (especially if your into more action games) just driving along roads and you'll find yourself, weaving in and out of traffic, breaking the speed limits etc.  By this point, I usually make a delivery run once a day say and then switch to another game, so still worth a look, albeit on sale.

This is by far currently the best simulator game of its kind, with a reasonable price (as well as occasionally being on sale and included in game bundles) and has regular updates and improvements to the game from the developers. Best of all the developers listen to and care about their community in regards to improving the game. The price is cheap for the core game, and its strap ons and extra maps, compared to other games. I mostly play online using the free unofficial multiplayer mod which is also regualrly updated, but sadly does disable some features of the game like hired drivers - no fault to the developers for this as they originally said multiplayer would not be possible for this game. For playing offline there are some other excellent free mods available including trucks, trailers and maps, although none of these (except officially released) are compatible with the multiplayer mod. I found the game difficult to play with the keyboard, so got a Logitech G27 wheel and pedals to play and makes the game so much easier to play and more enjoyable. It is also possible to play the game with an erection. While this game is still very much being improved and developed, the developers also post updates on an American truck simulator they are developing which sounds fantastic. I do hope the developers carry on what they are doing, and do nothing which would spoil the game or the enjoyment it is providing me with.

I normally play racing games & bought Euro Truck 2 for a bit of fun and something different. I was not expecting to play much more than about 10 hours in this game, but so far I have managed 39 hours & still enjoying it.  You start off doing quick jobs until you have enough money to purchase your own truck & start doing the freight market which is much more profitable.  You can purchase different trucks & upgrade different elements such as the chassis, engine, interior and the look of the truck. You can visit the paint shop to customise the exterior. It includes most of the manufacturers such as Volvo, Scania, Iveco, Man, Daf & Renault.  There is a management aspect to the game where you can employ drivers who will then start earning more money for you. You can expand your trucking empire by purchasing more depot's.  The driving is fun & handles as I would expect a truck to. The roads can be challenging & include a variety of junctions & road types to keep it interesting. I have mine setup with a Logtiech G27 which makes the experience much more involving. You have to haul various load types of loads to different European cities. The cities are representative of the cities but not an exact replica, so don't expect them to look like your local roads. Once you get to the destination you have the challenge of reversing your trailer in to the bay, which take a bit of practice. You can use a quick park if you find this difficult as the cost of XP points.  The game also has a large modding community to make the game more realistic such as physics & branded trailers.  If you like driving games & you feel like a change then give Euro Truck a try.

Great Fun all around for those who want a fix on big wheel driving.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is the greatest truck driving simulator, and possibly even the best simulator in general of all time. The game, even without any expansion packs is filled with content to the point of exploding. SCS Software made this game, it is the best game to own if you enjoy driving and owning or managing a business.  The trucks that you drive are based off of real trucks driven in real life. Truck companies like Iveco, Daf, Volvo and Scania all exist and not only that, but the models used in the game to resemble these trucks are extremely realistic in both sound and looks. All the trucks in the game are heavy and makes you feel like you’re actually driving a truck as opposed to driving a weightless car, there are penalties to speeding in this game besides getting a speeding ticket, but you could drift and slide unintentionally around the place and damage your truck's engine, suspension and more, whilst also damaging the cargo your delivering. Every truck shop you come across has more than one truck available for purchase, not even three, some shops have around six or seven. Each of those trucks have their own quirks and even that's not enough, not by a long shot, you can customize your truck with paint jobs, lights and even replace the 250hp engine for something with a more kick like a 500hp engine.  The map you play on is the most expansive map in any simulator, with what looks like over 100 roads to drive on, each with their own speed limits and occasionally road works, driving around this game is like a tourist drive in a tank. England not big enough for you? There are train tunnels and boat ports to carry your truck and cargo across the water and continue you on your way around Europe. If this isn't a big map with lots to see and drive on, I don't know what is.  Next is the tycoon part of Euro Truck Simulator 2. It's tough working your own company with you being the only employee, so you can hire other people and buy garages. All across Europe are cities (smaller than real life but even that doesn't ruin anything) and almost all of have a garage that you can buy with slots for vehicles, trucks available for purchase and a recruitment agency from which you can hire truck drivers to earn you some cash, or drive around looking for work and actually cost you money. But that's business.  The AI in Euro Truck Simulator 2 are fairly smart, not super smart as they do tend to drive and stop in front of you about 30cm away when you’re trying to do a U-turn. But that actually makes it realistic because anyone who drives in real life knows that you can't trust other people driving cars, some people are idiots and that's exactly what the AI in this are like. There is even a realistic bank to which you can get a loan for a quick cash injection and pay it back with interest. Pick the amount you want wisely because if you ask for a lot at the very beginning of your game, you'll find out that you will never pay it back.  All things considered, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is the greatest simulator of all time. Customization, driving, jobs, realism, expansion packs, AI and so much more. There is so much to do and all in one game by SCS Software. I myself have played the game for a long time, longer than my steam account says since I owned the game on disk, later buying it on steam because this is a game worth spending the money for, twice.  I rate this game 10/10. But only because when you rate out of 10 you can't go to about 100, where it deserves to be.

I recommend this game anyway, but I think you will enjoy it if you:  1: Are a real truck driver  2:Like driving games  3: Have a lot of time on your hands.  + Good graphics + Good sound and also radio + Feels like you are a real truck driver + A lot to do  - Takes a long time to get anywhere - Some irritating problems - Not every country in Europe :( - Sometimes too realistic  Total rating: 7,5/10

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game that you will either love or hate. Personally, I love it. I first started playing SCS's trucking games with the 18 Wheels of Steel series. A friend gave me a copy of American Longhaul and it got tossed on the shelf as I thought I would have no interest in it. A few months later I decided to install it and after half an hour of play I was hooked. I then went on to put many hours into all the games in the series.  I received ETS 1 in a bundle one day and set it aside to play at a later date, but I never got around to it. Then one day a friend of mine told me he had bought ETS 2 after playing my copy of ETS 1 through my shared library. He was one guy that I thought would not enjoy a truck driving simulator (in fact he originally ribbed me about playing 18WOS), so I was surprised when he started raving about it. That was enough for me to buy the game and all the DLC.  Once again, I am hooked on a trucking simulator and it is great. ETS 2 is leaps and bounds above all of the previous efforts by SCS, both in terms of visuals and gameplay. There is still the problem of braindead AI drivers, but that is something you will learn to anticipate and it does not become such a problem after a while. The visuals are stunning, you just have to look at some of the screenshots to see how pretty this game is, and the truck models are fantastic. All of the trucks feel different when you drive them and you will soon find your favourites and those that you loathe to drive.  With the addition of mods, especially some of the map mods available, the replay value of the game increases. There is even a multiplayer mod that regularly sees thousands of people on some of the servers. It is quite a sight to see hundreds of people lined up trying to get into Europort.  The game is also linked to the  World of Trucks  [www.worldoftrucks.com]  website which offers external contracts, events, and more. The site is only alpha at the moment, but with the imminent release of  American Truck Simulator  I can see more features being revealed.  As I said this is not a game for everyone, but if you like simulators and you like trucks then you will probably like this. As for whether to purchase or hold of for ATS, I would recommend buying this and then also ATS when it is released.  5/5

... No, this is not a joke.  This game is awesome. In way that are rather difficult to describe, this game keeps you entertained for a very long time. I spent hours just cruising around the highways, at times going for so long without a rest stop that my character began falling asleep.  There's something oddly intoxicating about Euro Truck Simulator 2. Visually, it's an impressive game. You'd expect the environments to be boring and repetitive, but they're not. Everything has a unique vibe and you can clearly distinguish industrial districts from the more rural ones.  There's really not much else to it. You need to play it to understand why it's entertaining. I suggest getting some of the mods that make the map bigger, though, since after a while driving from Dijon to Paris gets tedious.

Being a car guy, and really into simulation-style driving, I found this game to be perfect for me.   You can be a jackwagon, or 'good guy Greg' while doing long hauls across Europe. Driving country-to-country actually takes a decent amount of time, and really gives you that realistic trucking feel.  I often spend hours at a time completing one delivery after another.   On top of being able to drive yourself, you can hire AI drivers and build your own trucking company by buying garages in one of the many different cities.   THERE IS ALSO A MULTIPLAYER MOD. One of the best examples of simulators done right, furthermore more than 3 years after its release it still is supported and patched on regular basis. Furthermore, it is really relaxing, when I don’t want to play anything else I usually play this game or American Truck Simulator. All what you need to do is just drive by the rules of the road, the deadlines for deliveries usually allow for driving without a particular hurry. While doing that you can admire the world around you, which has some really stunning views especially in Scandinavia DLC. All of this combine into this relaxing and “zen” experience.  The game is still supported and patched, SCS said they are delivering same game engine patches as for American Truck Simulator, which is their newer game developed on the same engine. Not abandoning their older game after newer one has been released is a behavior of a game developer that should be supported. Furthermore there are tons of mods (including new trucks, maps, truck parts, loads, trailers, traffic and just about anything you could think of), some of them just are not on the Steam workshop, but you can easily download them outside the Steam. My favorite are trailer and traffic packs by Jazzycat, trucks by RJL and Ohaha, ProMods map and others, I really cannot mention here all the good mods that exist for this game. The game has even a mod loader that makes installing and running mods really easy. The support for steering wheels and gamepads is really good in my experience.  The most often valid complaint about the game is that it still does not support newer versions of DirectX. The AI sometimes does stupid things. But these really are not major problems. In case you are wondering do you need a steering wheel for this game my answer is you don’t but it makes the experience much better. The game is not hardcore simulation, it still has some gamey elements (for example some pneumatic systems of trucks are not simulated, you cannot buy your own trailers, etc.), but it is done to strike a balance between playability and simulation that would be most enjoyable.   If you are considering buying this game, I recommend getting “Scandinavia” and “Going East” DLCs, these add many interesting roads to drive through. All the rest DLC (at the time of writing this review) is purely cosmetic so you do not really need it.  Usually I recommend a game for a group of people that it best suits, but this is almost a universal recommendation from me. If you are a fan of driving or simulation games you should be already owning it. If you are not into simulation games, but you never really tried playing one this might be the one to try, especially on sale because you can get it ridiculously cheap then.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 - a near replica of real life 'trucking' which can be enjoyed by those who choose to relax after a long working day and feel as though they need a drive going from Aberdeen, Scotland to Paris, France. The next day they may want to move from Paris, France to Stockholm, Sweden and they may repeat this cycle for weeks on end; in other words, this simulator is a game that is addictive and relaxing for anybody.  The simulator comes with excellent graphics and gameplay, the feeling of driving an actual truck is there but not all the way there. When driving a truck, your body can feel the vibrations and movement which is not replicated in this simulator, even with a steering wheel. Furthermore, no simulator can be too large. This game misses out on a lot of important details and sections of Europe itself, mainly focusing on the Western European countries as opposed to the Eastern European countries such as Russia.  The game also accepts various mods and outside content to be implemented into the game, making for a better experience depending on what the content is. It could be a graphics upgrade, additional trucks, better lighting - anything which makes Euro Truck Simulator 2 feel more approachable by it's users, having the ability to perform actions which they wouldn't in numerous other games. The idea that users can share their mods with others on various forums makes for an excellent community spirit.  Despite having minor problems which could be described as rather petty problems made on my behalf, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is the greatest simulator to date and I encourage all readers to play this game and enjoy it.  Rating: 9/10

This is nice base trucking simulation ( only driving part included ), only 'few' annoying things on it:  - speed limits and signs need serious overhaul, way too bouncy speed limits and often getting ticket from driving with the car speed limit ( sometimes you have to drive way lower than car speed limit to avoid getting ticket, like in north side of france, speed limit 70, speed limiter tickets if you drive over 50 ) and sometimes speed limit changes not by speed limit sign, but by freeway sign or some other kind of sign  - speed limit signs nor street signs not showing in night without high beams and other car lights have pathetic visibility on night, pretty much invisible on your truck mirror  - street signs need serious overhaul, would be nice to be able to prepare for xroads obeying the street signs, but they hardly never show lane info correctly, always last sign showing right info ( giving you 1 second to adjust ), 2 previous ones showing wrong info  - npc cars have very low AI IQ, they dont see the player at all, thus specially at crossroads and just after customs gate they try to ram you, then you have to pay from crashing into them and to your employer from damaging the cargo, many times they crash into eachother or make traffic jams  - rain system at second lowest settings makes it feel like your in english summer... every day getting rain, turning it 1 more step down means no rain at all  - no online game... yet ( only alpha version atm )  - game has only 1 season, summer  - many xroads that have just 1 traffic light that hinders seriously those who wanna turn left, pretty much always they can turn left only by going over the line and waiting for the light to turn red, then hit the gas  - navigator many times makes you do extra turns into small roads, even when road going straight would be shorter and faster, specially makes you avoid trips through towns, no matter how big detour it makes you do  - would be nice if we could mark down to map to see what gas station has nice gas prices, often you cant even tell what the gas price is next to the gas station sign ( signs hardly never show real price, like britains prices always are 1.39.99 but gas pump charges 1.59 or trying to figure out what 413 or 51 price means )  But atleast it has netradio and navigator and you can run your own company and its drivers

Simulators... Boring? No. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is one of the best driving simulators out there. I wouldn't recommend playing with a keyboard, or even a controller. However, if you've got a racing wheel, then this game will keep you occupied. I have a Logitech G25, so playing this game is a lot of fun. This is due to the fact that the G25/G27 has both force feedback, and a separate gear stick. Without these, the game would feel a little 'flat'. Also, the introduction of Multiplayer (unofficial) makes this game a pleasure to play with friends, and the online community is bustling.

While this game may seem foolish, boring and dumb on the cover, it may be one of the best casual games I've played. Once you buy it, you're in for a real treat.  In this game, you run your own start-up company, transporting different goods from city to city. Eventually you build up your company enough to the point where you can buy yourself a truck, expand your garage, hire employees and buy them trucks as well.  This game has really taught me to be disciplined and patient on the road, no matter how badly EuroGoodies needs their cheese or Tree-ET needs their forklifts. You'll get there eventually.  Pros: Fun and Relaxing Game! Running your own business is quite fun! Beautiful graphics, if you have the computer for it. Really fun once you get into the thick of it! Once you have levelled up your driver, the capabilities you have when driving are a lot less limited. Lots of cities, especially a lot more with the DLCs.  Con: Speeding tickets everywhere, even if you are barely above the speed limit. I get a lot of these tickets in the UK, maybe they just hate me.  As I said in the beginning, this is a great casual game. It's fun and relaxing. Perfect for getting away from games that can leave you stressed such as CS:GO or another rather competitive game. This game helped me relieve stress.  If you love driving, running a business, Europe, or just a casual experience, you'll probably love this game.  It just happens that I am a fan of all of these.  9/10.

Now being a trucker and delivering trailers to point A to point B will come dull sooner or later. Now don't get me wrong there is plenty to do in base game, like building your own transport company. Now good dlc expansion would give you a some new challenges and game mechanics to keep you interested, lets say few like, left hand driving, (but thats already in base game) slippery snow roads, or double trailers that they use in Scandinavia.   But going east expansion is just a more stunning look scenery next to your multi-lane road, and everything interesting is not included in Scandinavia expansion. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is an incredible game. That's right, a simulator that is worthy of being called a game. It is still a simulator, and quite a good one at that, but unlike many other simulator 'games' out there, this one is enjoyable. It creates a very satisfying experience out of something that you would at first believe to be boring.  First of all, the game looks good. The sounds compliment this and, if you're getting tired of listening to the roar of your engine as you roam the roads of Europe, you can play your own MP3s from your computer through the in-game radio. Even better is the ability to stream internet radio stations through the in-game radio, which, when I first discovered, I was very pleased about it!  So what do you do in ETS2 exactly? Well, you can start off working for other trucking copmanies, taking valuable cargo from point A to point B, earning some money and experience points along the way. Once you start earning enough money (or decide to get a loan from the bank), you can then purchase your own truck instead of using other people's vehicles, allowing you to earn more money and even more EXP. EXP is what allows you to 'level up', which gives you skill points that you can allocate to various different skills, e.g. improved eco-driving or being able to take jobs that involve fragile cargo (better-paying jobs).  With the rest of the money you make, you can buy more trucks, upgrades/paint for said trucks, and most importantly employees who will work for you (and garages to place them in). Soon enough, you will be running the best trucking business in all of Europe, which is ultimately the aim of this game (to build up your business and have fun doing it!).  But what is the actual driving aspect of the game like, you might ask? Well, as I said before, you drive cargo from point A to point B and earn money whilst doing so. This may sound tedious and boring, but what makes it such a grand experience is a) the scenery (as you drive through a scaled-down version of Europe), b) the excellent vehicle physics and mechanics, and c) what you do with it all: are you going to play seriously, making sure to follow all road rules and never commit a speeding offence? Or are you just going to play casually, listening to your internet radio stations and free-roaming Europe without any cargo at all? Or perhaps you'd like to muck around with some friends on multiplayer (requires a mod), crashing into things and having fun doing it?  ETS2 is truly a magnificent experience that seems to offer little yet offers so much! I thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game and will most likely revisit it in the future. All I can say is this: if you want to drive around Europe in a truck, earning money and buying trucks as you do so, this is the game for you. And if you're skeptical, trust me, I was too. After playing it, though, I can tell you I had no regrets with it.  Enjoy! :)

Wow! I never thought in a million years this would be a title for me. I am embarrassed to admit I really enjoy this game. :)  You know what? This is more fun than most racing games. (explosion, whaaaaaaat???!!!!)  Well, how about no frustration, stress, monotonous scenery and bad realism. This games makes you feel calm, good and is truly a realistic simulator. You get more involved with your thoughts, it is even quite meditative.  When I first heard about this game, I thought: 'this game is definitely not for me. Perhaps for a nerd with a weird obsession about trucks. It just sounds like the most boring game ever. I mean just driving around a truck...?'   But after hearing more and more from reviewes, even from some that I regard highly, I decided to give the demo a try. Then it was dirt cheap during the sale...  Why I like it:  -Your 8 year old that always wanted to drive a truck gets all (s)he wanted gets to live again.   -The game runs great on most machines, and still looks great. Highly detailed.  -Real looking, beautiful and versatile ares.  -Realistic mechanics, but not frustrating to master. You actually get better at the game with no handholding.  -The game does not feel like a quick cash-in that so many simluators nowadays do. The game is well done.   -This game is also about running a business which is fun too.  -It is really satiesfying and calming to drive. (quite a surprise actually). It feels quite meditative, not boring at all.   -Radio. You either add your own favorite radio, or you listen to audiobooks. Fantastic.  -Weather. You feel quite snug in your truck while the weather thunders outside.  -Mods. Not really necessary, but why not? More stuff.  What I don't like:  -I don't want to admit to anyone I like this game. The least to my family... ;)  It works totally fine with mouse and keyboard. But I highly recommend a controller, or even better, a wheel for smoother driving. Make sure you go through the controller and game setup thouroghly. There are quite a few options to make the game suit your style - this is very good. You might find the game more enjoyable if you do. I imagine this game will be absolutely fantastic on a three monitor setup, and someone mentioned 3D works really well too. The immersion... I don't have this, but still enjoy the game.  Get it on a sale.

Right - so i just recently activated this game to steam, so don't get bothered by the amount of time I've played it, since i had already spent several DAYS playing this game. Aaaand... BUY IT RIGHT NOW! You won't regret it! BLoody hell, I thought this kind of game just COULDN'T be good! But man, was I wrong... There's just SO MANY OPTIONS! You can work for other people to afford a truck, then you can buy your own truck, customize it, get better parts for it, you can hire a driver, then give them your truck, while you work for other people to afford a new truck for yourself.   The drivers level up as they go on missions themselves, giving you a bigger income. There's a huge truck market letting you choose from all types of different trucks. Including DAF, MAN, Ivedo, Renault, Majestic, Scania and Volvo. There's DLC letting you go all the way to poland, and most of Europe. It has all these different kinds of simulation like air brake - pressure simulation, fatigue simulation.... You need to refuel as well as stop every now and then to doze off for a bit. There's fines for going past red lights, there's speed cameras, there's damage to your truck, even though it doesn't show all the bulks and damage, you nearly CAN'T drive it when it's more than 70% of damage. The vechicles feel HEAVY, and that is the best thing! Also, remember to turn off the speed limiter that doesn't allow you to go past 90 km/h or 60 mph. Then it just gets really fun ;)

Now this is what you call an actual Simulator, not that crap like Tree Simulator, Grass simulator, Toilet Simulator and ♥♥♥♥ing firefighters simulator. You can drive around Europe (missing some countries like Sweden you need DLC for that).
