'Comfy Truck Simulator' - Most people would turn away and laugh at this game. Those people have obviously never sat down and played ETS2 for themselves. This is truely a unique driving game. While not action-packed like action racing game, ETS2 offers a niche driving experience that allows the player to take control of their own truck and run their own company. The game world is detailed and very accurate. Follow traffic laws to avoid getting slammed by fines, and well.. avoid slamming into things as well, because the consequences of bad driving can deal a serious blow. Haul cargo across Europe's varying landscapes and bustling cities, listen to the radio (which are actual live streamed radio stations from Europe), or listen to your own tunes. Personally, I feel this game can really help you relax and unwind. Try the demo out first (about 4-5 hours of gameplay), and just sit back and drive.

Best served with your favourite radio station.   Jokes aside, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a well made relaxing truck driving game. It's not much a 'simulator' in the exact meaning of the word, i'd say it's more a simulator adaptation for everyone to enjoy and not only die hard fans.   Playing Euro Truck Simulator you drive all around a stylized Europe, from country roads to highways, mostly pleasurably detailed and with the precision of signs and traffic laws you'd expect from a simulator.  What I found a bit annoying were strange intersections (you will never find intersections that take a lane away), not being able to refill in towns (every real town has at least a gas station), lack of content for non-central Europe states (you cannot go to Sicily for example)  On the other end I really liked the AI of other cars/vans/trucks, they mostly react like human drivers would to unforeseen events.   EDIT: In recent free updates (following the release of the new 'Scandinavia' expansion) the whole graphics got a huge rework and since most concerns of my previous review were about the 'poor' graphic implementation, they are all gone. The game now looks fabulous with no impact on performance (actually if feels even better). The developers also solved a few issues so that the game is more realistic and even more a pleasure to be played.  While before the 'Scandinavia' expansion this game for me was a little more than 7/10 now it's definitely 9/10. Good job SCS Software. Recommended to everyone able to use a PC.

What is it with this game?  It seems pretty straightforward: you drive trucks. In Europe.  Yet, once you get on the road for your first transport, you're kinda hooked. It's always 'just one more job'. And it's 4 am. And you have to get up in three hours.  'Just one more job'.   There's something mesmerizing about driving a truck, loaded with cargo, from one city to another. You turn on the radio, go into cruise control and keep an eye on the road. Time flies, Getting jobs done is rewarding, you get cash that you can invest in a new truck or building your empire, which means hiring drivers and getting trucks for them. Your AI drivers will look for jobs and level up, developing their skills in the process.  Starting your career is a slow process, so this game surely isn't something for the impatient among you. Also, there's not much happening. You just drive. Sometimes you need to brake or turn, but aside from that, there's not much stress.  But you keep spending countless hours playing it, I just don't understand this phaenomenon.  Oh, and the user interface is superb. Self explanatory and logical, very well done.  The graphics are nice, but you won't have much time to admire the views. They don't put much of a strain on your graphics card, so the game should run well on older computers.  So, do I recommend ETS2?  Yes, definitely. It's a solid product, and if you like a game in which you can actually relax, listen to some music and have fun without shooting people. A very interesting title for any player who owns a steering wheel.

As someone who has played nearly all of SCS Software's back catalogue I have been longing for the day when they will come up with something that actually looks like this century and, lo and behold, 2 years ago they did!  For a game that is quite simply 'drive a truck with cargo from a to b' it is surprisingly simple yet complex in its own unique way. For a game that may not look as polished as AAA titles it does look pretty in its own little way, from the detailed trucks to the landscape that, in some cases, look as close to their real life counterparts as you will get in a computer game. Sure there are things that could be improved but what I will say is whilst others will moan that they are taking too long in releasing things like their next map DLC all I will say is just be glad it isn't the pre-ETS2 days where you would be lucky to get even one patch!  TL;DR: buy this game and chillax! ;)

This game definitley deserves a thubms up. İ an not a truck driving veteran and i do not know much about things like retarder or air brake. But i am sure that these details are crucial for truck driving. This is a realy nice openworld simultions game for even rookie truck drivers.  Here are the cons that i can see: Tha games graphics card req is high but the environment is not that good looking. Even with my R9 380 i can see occasional fps drops on ultra settings @1080. This is not a downside but when radio is playing in the truck, there should have been some echo or accustics or something like that. If you have played farcry 3, there are veichles and you hear radio is playing while driving. In this game, it is like an excluded music player. There is traffic in this openworld game and the ai is not that smart. Sometimes they can smash into your truck while you are coming out of a full repair :) AI should be avoding crashes. Cuz sometimes they are just blind. This is not a con but if it is an openworld game and there is traffic, there has to be an option for traffic density. It would be realy nice to see lots of cars on the roads or no cars at all. When the game gets an update, it termintates your ongoing saved mission and pays you for it. I don't want the money, i want to complete my mission. The game is getting frequent updates and this is sometimes annoying. The map can be a little bit less repetitive with some additions. I think it is a little bit hard to make money. I mean if you want a fully upgraded scania truck, you have to play for like a 100 hours. This is my subjective opinion, some people may think that it should be hard to get a truck like that. Your choice. There are lots of dlc for this game. 2 of them are expansions to the map and others are paint jobs and interior decorations. I think 1 is for heavy cargo. Some of these dlc should not be dlc. They should be standart issue.  And i do not see any other downsides. Here are the pros: Map is big enough so you can spend hours in the game. If you do not mind repeating environments, you will have lots of quality time :) There are lots of control and driving options. This is an important requirement for a simulations game. There are options for seat position, mirrors and light adjustments, break intensity, rain probability, trailer stability ... etc. There is a cruise control. There is an in-game radio, so you are not stuck with your truck roaring all the time. You can also create your playlist with your own music. There is a company management system. Which means you are not alone in the game and this is cool. It is also a faster way to make money. There are occasional pedestrians. It feels like a live action game. There should be more of them here and there. Which reminds me, it would be nice to see some crashes on the road. Maybe a truck turned upside down and some people are helping the driver. Or a car going off the road while driving. So i can say, holly ****, that dude was too fast and he deserved it :) Truck sounds are realistic. They are actually recorded live. You can play with keyboard, gamepad or a wheel and they all have their specific options. There are camera controls to help you check the corners. You do not have to use mouse to look around. There are different camera angles, you can drive from outside if you want. There are traffic tickets for speeding or passing through red light. There is a penalty for avoding sleep :) You start dozing if you do not sleep for too long. There are a variety of trucks with their own characteristics.  So this is all i can say objectively about this game. If you don't mind repeating environment and long play times, this is an addictive simulation game.

The best out of all simulators in my opinion.  Euro Truck Simulator 2 has been out for quite a while and has changed at lot since the start. With map expansion DLCs such as 'Going East' and 'Scandinavia', there is so much more to explore and with the upcoming 'Vive La France' there will be even more to explore. With the additional DLC, you're sure to find a place of your liking to have as your truck HQ  There is a good variety of trucks, the 7 makes in the game are: Scania, Volvo, Iveco, MAN, DAF, Mercedes-Benz and Renault. Some of these trucks have a couple of different models but there is sure to be something you'll like. A range of different cabin sizes so if you prefer a small sleeper truck you can have that, or the much larger sleeper cabins. If you want to take things a step further, you can modify the exterior of your truck with accessories and of course even pick some paintjobs. There is additonal DLC which you can buy which will allow you to modify the interior of your truck, let you pick from a wider range of paintjobs and more.  This game has a lot to offer, if you like driving (trucks especially) then this is sure to be a game for you.

Don't overthink it. It's a game about doing deliveries with a truck and possibly managing a delivery of goods service. But this game is a jewel in it's simplicity! You'll find yourself losing hours upon hours of your time doing these deliveries as the relaxing experience delivered by the title engulfs you.  Pick your favorite Netflix show or podcast and just take an afternoon off delivering something to an exotic country in Europe.

There was a time when I used to watch gameplay of this on YouTube. There was a time when I couldn't afford it, and so had to use my knowledge of Google in order to play it. I wanted to support the developers, and eventually could afford to buy the game.   Since then, I've spent countless hours with a controller in my hand, driving down motorways, mountain passes and all over Scandinavia. I can honestly say that this game is hands down my favourite hobby (besides climbing IRL, but who needs that when you can drive all day?).  If you're thinking about buying this game, stop. Stop thinking. Just do it. So scroll on back up and press that 'Add to Cart' button.   On a serious note, it's easy to cross your arms and say 'Hmph, only a loser would play this type of thing' but really, it is SO easy to take a passive stance and judge something before you try it, but ETS2 has been like a book for me. It's my escape, my passion and my drive.

This is my first ever review on Steam, and I must say I never expected to write my first review for ETS2. I bought it during the recent Summer Sale and took a chance on it. Going in I knew from experience that I loved sim games, but I was just expecting this one to be silly.   I couldn't have been farther from the truth. There are some limits to the sim sure, but this looks and feels like you actually are trying to build a trucking empire across Europe. This is now my go-to game when I want something a bit slower paced and relaxing. I highly recommend for anyone that plays to download a bunch of podcasts or audiobooks that you have been wanting to catch up on or maybe you haven't listened to before. (Check out NPR's Serial podcast series)   This function in the game really sells it for me, I can catch up on all my latest football (soccer) podcasts and also listen to great stories all while working towards having a massive trucking empire across Europe. I suggest playing with a Steam controller or another controller if you don't have one to make the steering a bit easier, or you could go whole hog and buy a steering wheel. Just remember to customize and tweak until you find all of the buttons and steering to your liking.  I plan on buying American Truck Simulator once I've had my fill of ETS2 and I couldn't be more thankful that I took a chance and added a great sim series to my library.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a... Truck simulator where you drive around Europe! You start by doing jobs for other truck companies before you have enough money to buy your own truck and work for your own company, you're your own boss before you have enough money to hire other people that will drive trucks for your company bringing in more money. There is a level and progression system to unlock upgrades for your truck and be able to do longer journeys with different cargo like fuel or explosives, but something that Euro Truck lacks is a meaning to all these different trailers besides the looks of it, why should I drive carefully with explosives on the back of my truck when I know it can't explode? why should I have care for my cargo? could I damage it and lose whats inside? there is a damage system where when you crash into something, either your truck or your trailer gets damage, the higher the damage on your cargo, the less pay, the more damage on your truck the more it stalls and beeps at you telling you that you are a horrible driver and that you need to spend money on getting it fixed. Euro Truck also has a fuel system to fuel up your HUGE tank, this never really occurs tho as it takes less than 2 minutes to full up and its always less than 1,000 euro to fuel up and you get way more than that every time you do a trailer job.  In short, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is only fun if you like trucks and driving (This game has AMAZING FFB support for wheels) there is no real consequence for bad driving other than fines and damage, creating lack for care of your truck and cargo.

Don't expect an adrenaline rush in this game, or to be racing round corners at 200mph. It is a Truck Simulator after all. Even if you tried the demo soon after it was released and didn't like it because of the amount of bugs or lack of content, give it another try. Free developer patches provide continual new content (since release - all brands are licensed except Mercedes, with 3 new trucks added to the game and another coming soon) on top of paid DLCs and free fan-made addons, some of which are truly remarkable. Definitely buy the game. And don't even think about piracy, as the trailers will disappear and your truck will turn PINK.

You'd think that a game called Euro Truck Simulator would be dull and uninspired but that is not the case. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is an incredibly well made game, its many pieces fall into place to create a thoroughly enjoyable and engaging experience.  The game has an impressive sense of progression, as you climb the ladder of the trucking world you go from being a cap for hire, running odd jobs for companies, to a trucking magnate, running an entire network of truck drivers and pulling in hundreds of thousands of Euros a day.  Euro Truck 2 also looks really impressive, the trucks are modeled superbly and the European scenery is always pleasant. But the most impressive feature is the ability to stream actual radio stations in-game. Nothing creates more immersion than listening to Liverpool's Rock Radio (Which doesn't really play much rock music) while running a shipment of Yogurt between Sheffield and Swansea.  Euro Truck 2 is a bloody good time, if you're even slightly interested I recommend checking out the demo, it gives a sizable chunk of the game to play around with.
This game is fun, and multiplayer is out! So you can drive around and play with your friends!!!  9/10!

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding lemon bars recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1) 2 cups Flour 2) 1/2 cup Sugar 3) 1/4 teaspoon Salt 4) 2 sticks (1 Cup) Salted Butter, Cut Into Small Cubes 5) Filling 6) 1-1/2 cup Sugar 7) 1/4 cup Flour 8) 4 whole Large Eggs 9) Zest And Juice Of 4 Medium-sized Lemons 10) Powdered Sugar, For Sifting  Directions:  1. For the crust: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grease a 9-by-13-inch pan with butter.  2. Stir together the flour, sugar, and salt. Add the butter to the bowl and use a pastry cutter to cut it all together until the mixture resembles fine crumbs. Press into the prepared pan and bake until golden around the edges, about 20 minutes.  3. For the filling: Stir together the sugar and flour. Crack in the eggs and whisk to combine. Add the lemon zest and juice and mix until combined. Pour over the crust and bake about 20 minutes.  4. Allow to cool in the fridge for a minimum of 2 hours, then sift powdered sugar over the top before cutting into squares.  (Use an 8 x 10 pan if you'd like the layers to be a little thicker.)

Can't believe I've reviewed American Truck Sim but not this...  A very realistic and fun simulator based around trucking in Europe, the only problem is that it basically has no anti-aliasing.  The sim itself is fairly good-looking, and sports a pretty large map, and variety of cargo. However, modding takes this beyond what SCS could ever envision, gigantic highly-detailed maps, thousands of different cargos, new trucks from all over the world, and enough extra content to talk about for days.  I'd highly recommend this game to anyone intersted in trucks/trucking/driving/good simulators, or any combination.

I started off this game normally . Driving trucks around Europe, my average speed being 90 km/h. They were some good times, despite my adequate graphics settings . Then, I started to feel... Boredom. I was shocked, but I knew this day was to come for a [slow] driving game. I searched online 'How to go faster in ETS2' and found.... the solution. To turn of the speed limiter. I have never looked back since.   Now I drive around Europe, pimped with my 'No Damage' Mod, driving at around 120 km/h [80-90mph]. Ocassionally crashing on those nasty sharp corners and roundabouts (Oh who am I kidding, I crash everywhere) BUT it doesn't mater, my truck and cargo is INVINCIBLE! I do get fines sometimes for smashing into people's cars at full speed with a truck.

If you are a fan of Europe, trucks, or driving for extended periods of time on the wrong side of the road, pick up this game.

Well made trucking simulator. You start your career in a wheel of someone elses truck and build your company up from a scratch. Concept goes: buy a truck, pick a job, pick up the load, drive to the destination, empty the load, repair/upgrade/fuel your truck and learn new skills. After awhile you can afford a second truck and can hire one extra driver. A lot of attention has been put to details. There's dynamic weather system, day/night cycle, traffic violations, AI traffic, etc.  There are many new cities to discover and you can use ferries and train tunnel to reach UK from mainland Europe. I recommend Going East and High Power Cargo pack DLCs as they're quite cheap and extend the map and available delivery missions. Scandiavian DLC is also on it's way.  There's a lively modding community around ETS2, good player made maps, multiplayer and expansions. A steering wheel is recommended, but I found mouse & keyboard fine aswell. This game supports Naturalpoint TrackIR and Oculus DK1/2 for those who have them.   In my opinion the learning curve of this game is low, though some basic knowledge about trucks can be useful. To me, it's not a hardcore simulator.

AI cars (specifically large trucks) sometimes stop completely if you bump into them slightly in a narrow street. The DLC packs come with a couple of bad paint jobs but some great ones. Overall the game itself is great 9/10.

10/10; will truck again. Came back after 2 years and love it again.  TL;DR: There is a demo. It's very good, I don't know how you would improve honestly other than a graphical update.  A suprisingly fun game that is challenging in the driving mechanics, offers light RPG elements via leveling up your driver to take on better jobs, economic game elements by building up your corporation with more garages and drivers doing things in strategic places, integration into an streaming service so you can stream a lot of different music while you play, most importantly a hypnotic experience that truely warms your cockles having fun in the simulation, and gives you that rush when completing and starting missions to keep on truckin'. Wow, that pun was unintended but apt. Very deftly done, Nooch.  There is a demo, which hooked me, so if you haven't tried out this game for 10 minutes you're simply robbing yourself of a rich experience.   Pros: - Fun challenge in simulation - RPG elements - economic game elements - good streaming music integration (or your own MP3s) - relaxing! And I'm not easily relaxed - one-more-mission addictive element  Cons: - graphics are contemporary, and it's a few years old - Interface can be awkward, but it's not a traditional genre so standards are not well-defined.

If you had to nitpick the bad parts of this game you could say that the AI isn't very good, or that their isn't a FOV slider. Euro Truck Simulator 2.  What can be said about this game that hasn't been said already. It is quite fun to play. I have approximately 20 hours in the game, and that's about where I'd say most users that would be interested in this, would get to. For someone more casual, and not into the 'sim' genre (think... the person that plays flight simulator, and the first thing they do is nose it over into the ground because they wanted to see what the crash looked like)... you're probably looking at about 5 hours.  Pros: The game is good, it's well oiled, and a complete package. You'll have no problem picking it up, driving for miles, and running an RPG style trucking company if you'd like, or you could simply roam about in the countryside racking up speeding fines.  Cons: They types of loads get a bit repetitive, and I think the developers are missing a HUGE opportunity for a CHALLENGING trucking sim. Spin Tires goes further than it needs to (though still a FANTASTIC game), but where Spin Tires is all mud, and challenge... ETS2 is all highway, and cruise control. Adding a variety of loads to carry, and the challenge of mountain trucking, or big city fuel tanker deliveries, etc... would make this game much more interesting.  Still, the mod community is strong. I prefer not to mod, since they're largely just skins, which I find provide nothing more than (no pun) a skin deep experience.  Buy it if: You're fascinated by running a freight business as an owner/operator, and enjoy the long haul aspects of FSX.  Skip it if: You're looking for something that requires you to think your way through something, or do more than remember to indicate properly, and back a big rig into a loading dock. True story, I've fallen asleep while driving on the virtual highway on a longhaul... which is probably realistic... but not the kind of realism I want in a game.  I'm giving it a 7/10 if you don't mod. I wish there was more variety in the challenge of loads (long loads, doubles, triples, oversized, etc.), and the traffic AI seems to leave something to be desired.

Yes, it's nerdy.   Yes, it's just driving a truck from A to B.   However, if you are looking for something unique that isn't dealing death to millions of identikit villains or being a one-person saviour of the universe, why not give Euro Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) a try?  I recently moved from Xbox 360 back to the PC scene. In the years that I had an Xbox, I found that I really missed the kind of games that only PC has. Games where essentially nothing happens. The world won't end if you don't achieve your objective.  This is why I like ETS2.  This is an extremely well-supported game. The publishers regularly issue free updates (not just bug fixes, but additional cities, road networks, trucks, etc).   I have sunk hours into this game just driving a truck from one city to another, and then another city, etc. It is a great way to while away time with no stress. Although the roads and cities are very loosely based on the real-life versions, I don't think that you could ever hope to compare game vs. real-world with any degree of accuracy. Having said that, there are certain roads that I have travelled in-game and in real-life and found myself thinking 'wow, they got that right!', so must be an element of consideration of the real-world road network.  Controls were initially an issue, but a recent update fixed that with proper Xbox controller support. Performance-wise, the game has never crashed or had any technical problems at all. It runs at max settings on my PC (which is fairly high-spec, so I would expect that!)  My main criticisms are minor; the graphics can seem a little bleached out / over-saturated (in HDR mode especially), sometimes the AI drivers create a bottleneck where they all block a junction waiting for a vehicle to turn - this causes the lane that the vehicle needs to cross to become blocked (I had to barge my way through the roadside to get past!). Another minor complaint is that the roads seem very under-populated. If possible, there needs to be an option to increase AI traffic.  All in all, I love ETS2 and would recommend it to anyone looking for a game to pass time in.

When I first bought this I thought to myself 'This'll be bloomin' awful'... how wrong I was.  I bought this game to laugh at it, I've bought many simluators in the past 'for a laugh', I thought this was going to be no different.   Making the profile was comical. I even found a picture of Ellen DeGeneres which I ended up choosing for my trucker. I called my company something 'funny' like 'Les-Be-Friends'. Just the usual for me when starting a new simulator game...  But then the game started and I was awestruck.   The graphics are beautiful. Very detailed and well designed.   The game physics aren't a piece of ♥♥♥♥ like they are on usual simulators.  The sound effects are brilliant. No complaint from me.  Now... the gameplay.  When I did my first job/mission, I didn't take it seriously; I caused as much damage as possible. I maybe lasted about 30 minutes before I closed the game and went to bed. The next morning I had an urge to finish it and so I did. That was the moment I got hooked onto this.   I've now started taking it seriously, abiding by the laws of the road, stopping at traffic lights... I've even bought myself a wheel controller just so I can feel even more immersed in the game.   This game is what simulators should be. Euro Truck Simulator 2 and OMSI are the REAL simulators not Farm Simulator 2012, Woodcutter 2013 etc.  I was never interested in trucks or driving but now I love it. If anybody has actually gotten this far in my review, then please try this game because I was just as uninterested as you are and now look at me!   10/10 - I reccomend this game A LOT.  PS: There is currently a brilliant Mod out for this game that enables multiplayer. It takes no time to get it working, you only have to install it... nothing else.   The mod allows you and your friends to truck as one. You will come across a lot of other people too. I just went on multiplayer and there was over 2,000 people playing. It isn't littered with trolls either as they are quickly banned for blocking roads, purposely banging into other players etc etc.   This adds to the game even more. So please, try this game out or forever be known as an idiot!

Generally I consider the game to be poor and weak. It is not for people who like realism. If there was a better game I would not recommend this one. I guess it's like the saying 'One-eyed is the king among the blind.'  When I was buying the game it was very cheap... like 5 Euros... I would never want to pay 20 for it. It's not worth it.  positives: + It's the only truck simulator game I know about + It's in Europe and has Slovakia included + It has a simplistic transport company management incorporated + Most of the time it is fun + Many truck types and the possibility to adjust and tweak your trucks + Semi-realistic handling - if you go too fast into a sharp curve, the trucks steering might lock due to the tilt, what I kinda like. I still miss a further realism, though  negatives - the game is absurdly static. After a while I got bored by the sceneries always being the same, roadworks being at the same place all the time, the only dynamics being provided by the traffic - there are no objectives in the game. If there were other companies you would be trying to beat, I believe that would be great - there is no way to see your whole truck fleet or to meet other of your trucks on the road - the traffic accidents - a car bumps into you, you get a fine despite the fact you haven't caused the accident, and if you don't get a fine, you're left with a damaged truck/load and no financial compensation, hitting the mileposts even in slow speed (which in reality are from plastic) causes heavy damage, I managed to hit a barrier at the side of the road with the side of a truck and had heavier damage than after a rollover - the truck models damage is another thing - the models are compact with no deformation damage showing, so you can have 30% damage and the truck looks ok. Once your engine is damaged, it might die during running without immediatelly stopping the truck, what I really don't consider very realistic  - static radars - once you know where they are, you can keep speeding on any other roads - the scenery is many times unrealistic, placing forests and hills, where there are none, etc. - absurd traffic rules - like crossings without traffic lights of a standard rod with a highway, automatic fine for your wheel crossing the line on traffic lights controlled crossroads, etc. - my truck once suddenly started to bounce and then exploded - no slippery roads - there is no winter in the game (or perhaps I still need to find out ) and even during the rain the truck handling isn't changing. I have never experienced with strong breaking, that the trailer would slip sideways - no older european trucks are available - helloween trucks in the DLC can't have the base color changed

Euro Truck Simulator 2 puts you in the shoes of a truck driver. You start out as any regular bloke being a hired driver and delivering various things with a given truck.  After a few jobs you have the option to get a loan from the bank to buy your very own truck. This is where the game truly opens. With your own truck you can drive around anywhere in the map and explore it as you please. Jobs give a higher pay so you can profit something while also paying off your debt. After some jobs the bank will offer you another loan, so you can start your very own trucking company. You use that money to buy a few trucks and hire drivers to work for you.

The haters are gonna hate, but the simulators are gonna simulate, and the haters are going to miss out on the best PC driving game since Stunts came out over 22 years ago.  Simulation games are all about trying something that you would otherwise not be able to do in real life; its not like most people have ever even met a truck driver before, let alone had the chance to become one, its kinda like being an astronaut: only the best of the best ever have a hope of getting behind that wheel. So if you didn't have perfect grades in highschool, and don't have PHD level degree in engineering, finally here is your chance to haul apples from Munich to Frankfurt in a 40 ft trailer!  But seriously, Euro Truck Sim 2 is a perfect example of a game that really shouldn't work, but does. Lets face it the subject matter is horrible, it simulates a job that I can tell you from experience most people would gladly walk away from and never return if they didn't have a mortgage and 2 kids at home. But somehow the beautifully rendered European scenery, the generally really good physics, the open world gameplay, and the lite buisness sim gameplay provide just enough to make this a really good game. I find that rather than feeling like I am at work when I play it, its always `just one more haul`, so I can do X, and it becomes really addictive.  Players that have played `cargo trading` games before such as Wing Commander privateer or Freelancer will feel right at home here, although instead of getting shot at, its all about safe driving and good route choices. Strongly recommend it to anyone who wants a good casual driving game with a fun economic rpg built in. If you hate driving games in general, or are generally more action oriented in your game choices maybe take a pass on this one.

Probably the biggest waste of time since minecraft, but since minecraft it has also occupied so many of my hours Its astounding, Great if you feel like you need somthing to do or if you wanna learn the the shift pattern of a truck, with some editing(or fourm browsing) you can get yourself a 18 speed truck and then learn that 9 speed layout.   My only real gripes with this game are the citys are extremely small, you have to use a clutch, (you cannot rev match to shift) and the gearshift doesnt track itself, you can shift into gear then let the clutch out and drag the stick into the next and nothing will change untill you push the clutch. Shifting could use some work.  And for the love of (insert your deity here) Optomize this GAME!!! 15 FPS in citys with 2 R9 280x's is unacceptable guys!  Bottomline, I would reccomend this game. If you run in eyefinity the games not quite fast enough, but at 1080p there should be no problems for any decent dual core (no Quad support, it runs but better if you limit it to two) with a throw in dedicated graphics at High, my laptops integrated intel can run at about medium.  So give it a try especially if its on sale, If you get away and have better than 30 FPS you will love it, Under 30, you will get frustrated at times but at the same time you will still have that urge to play it.

ETS2 is a very casual truck driving sim. You manage your own company with garages all over Europe, and buy trucks and hire drivers to get things running. While your drivers will find jobs by themselves, and do not really need your input, you can either do jobs for other companies, or do the jobs with your own truck. Or simply go freeroaming if you're in the mood for that.  The driving itself works great. Easy controls and fairly realistic physics. I have no complaints here.  Graphics are good. Not great, but decent enough for me. Music and sound effect are also good, but there's no music while you drive. However, you can either add mp3s to a playlist, or tune in on internet radio channels, if you want to.  I only have two issues with this game, none are gamebreaking:  1. Traffic AI is sometimes kinda silly, but they are constantly working on improving it. 2. No cloud save. This means that if I want to play in my house, then continue in my apartment, I have to copy save files and bring them with me. Very annoying for those of us who lives two places with a stationary PC both places.  If you'd like a casual driving sim, without the big challenges, this is the game for you. I recommend you get the Going East DLC too, as it adds more countries, and remember to check out the Scandinavia DLC when it gets released. The rest of the DLCs are just paintjobs for your trucks, I don't recommend spending a lot of money here, get them while on sale, which they often are.

Before I begin let me tell you this: This is one of the best simulators I have played of all time. And I have played a lot.  [Realism] The Creators of Euro Truck Simulator 2 (SCS Software) did their research on this style, it not only captures the raw nature of truck driving, but also the feeling of coming out into the world of truck driving. I talk not from personal expierence but one of second hand as family does drive trucks for a living, but in the United States.  [Fun Factor] I may not be overly interested in driving a truck throughout Europe, but this game makes that so entertaining and fun. After several hours I already am transfixed and addicted to driving, it's almost meditative to me. But also, after a long day of people ticking me off, it is also lovely to make a save and simply demolish every person on the road.  [Polish] Graphics high or low this game has an extraodinary amount of detail, when driving down a road it doesn't feel like the road is repeated over and over at all, it feels like I'm GOING somewhere, not many simulators capture that these days. If you look closely you can also see so much detail in the skys, from clouds brewing before it rains to airplanes passing by every now and again.  [My Recommendation] Buy this game, but I would highly recommend using either a gamepad/Xbox controller or an actual steering wheel but keyboard works just fine.  [Cons] Once you get into the meat of the game and buying garages it can sometimes feel unrealistic with your drivers just bustling around on their own free will and you can't actual request they take a certain job. But that is my only complaint.

Seriously, download the demo and try it out yourself.  It's driving trucks, but it's so much more.   I'll never forget my first delivery. I had to deliver coal and the very first turn in the game I took too sharp and the truck tipped over. I damaged the cargo and had to pay a fee to get my truck towed nearby. After that I missed several turnoff points to get to my destination, blew a few red lights which cost euros, and hit a few cars, costing more euros. I finally arrived about an hour past the delivery time. At the end of that, not only did I not get paid, I owed the bank about 3,000 Euros. I learned. Now I've got my own trucks and people work for me!

I thoroughly enjoy this game. 9/10.  At first I was skeptical about getting the game over a bestselling AAA blockbuster. Though the Christmas Sale discount nudged me in the right direction. From the moment I set out on the road in my MAN truck, I fell in love with Euro Truck Simulator 2.   The driving is genuinely realistic and had me thinking 'how can you get driving more on point than this on a laptop?' Driving through sunny (for a change) London, setting out on the highways and filling up fuel at the rest stops with my radio blaring, is unexplainably relaxing. You would have to experience it for yourself to know what I mean.   + Beautiful graphics + Realistic driving simulation + Detailed vehicles and landscapes + Many locations + Variety of vehicles, customization + Relaxing mood, stress relieving (at times not so much, but that's mostly my fault, damn the existance of other cars!)  - Lack of people on the streets & weather snaps me back to the reality that I am playing a game - Cities and landscapes start looking too similar, and not unique to cities and regions  Euro Truck Simulator is as close as I've gotten in a simulation to the real driving experience so far. I've been pleasantly suprised and have had my fair share of hours driving across various roads and highways, peacefully holding down a button with my finger.  9 points out of 10 to Gryffindor!

The updates improved the scenery and the AI traffic, but occasionly the traffic slows down and stops for no reason. The go east pack is good as the roads and scenery are good.  Plus there is loads of mods to have, from yank tanks to old Russian Maz and Ural trucks!

I swear they changed the graphics. Instantly upgraded the scenery. I love it. Not sure about the AI, but now traffic lights project the light colour onto the ground and that makes me so happy. I'm so glad they're still improving this game. 10/10 A must buy, and definitely one of my favourite games. The fact that my rating for this game is going up through the years just means that at this rate, Euro Truck Simulator 2 will just keep growing. Thank you for all your hard work devs!  TL;DR: This game is worth every single penny.

I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who enjoys driving simulators, drives trucks for a living or just enjoys trucking as a whole. There are so many great features to this game and awesome upgrades from the original Euro Truck Simulator that it is awe inspiring. There are a couple cons, yes, but they are FAR outshadowed by the pros.   PROS:  GREAT truck selection. From Volvo to DAF, from MAN to Iveco, from Renault to SCANIA, you are completely covered.  All trucks are able to be customized in a plethora of ways Driving is fun with your trucks performance affected by the weight of the load in realistic fashion i.e Engine working harder while going uphill, takes longer to gain momentum with a full load from dead stop etc Graphics are nice and clean for trucks themselves as well as the loads you haul Expansive map Many many more  CONS: Steering can get a bit clunky without a steering wheel. (I use keyboard and controller in varying degrees as I can't justify laying down close to $100 for a steering wheel to play a single game) Game time can become a pain in the ♥♥♥ when you try and figure out how far you can drive and how much you have to do before the day ends and your loan installment is taken from you NPC driver AI can be a bit stupid at times Towns are not very well fleshed out in places and highway driveby areas are rather plain and dull  All in all though, I highly recommend the game as it is a great way to unwind from your day while you wind up gears and truck on down the highway leaving all your problems behind like a lot lizard at the truck stop.  9.5/10

My friends that have played this game on my computer started off with the same reaction as you might have: 'Are you serious?' And then after an hour I have to peel them off of the wheel because they don't want to stop.  Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a leisurely driving game. You find jobs, pick up loads, haul them, and park the trailer on the other end. Along the way you'll follow your GPS, watch some beautiful sunrises, and watch the scenery pass by. Eventually you'll amass enough wealth to buy your own truck (and keep more profits), expand your garage, and then your fleet, and hire other drivers. But the real fun is listening to the wealth of internet radio stations the game has pre-programmed. When you're cruising over the mountains of Bavaria with Johnny Cash piping through the speakers (and a beverage of choice in your hand), you'll get why this game is fun.

Tipped my truck turning off the freeway...charged my employer for towing.   This is an unbelievably addicting game. You start out pulling jobs for random companies to make a buck, building up an earning to buy your own truck. Once you've obtained the beast, hit the open roads of Europe and make an empire for yourself. There is nothing quite like driving across a country highway with fields and hills on either side listening to British radio. I've played very few simulators in the past, but this one got me hooked in the first few minutes. A bit of configuration is needed to get comfortable, but it's quite easy straight off the bat.  -The AI is quite decent...they drive better than many real people do. They're poor brakers though, so don't drive out in font of them! -AI do make poor decisions though, just like real drivers. Beware. -Day/night cycle -Open map -Realistic driving experience -Online radio  Remember, the English drive on the left side of the road...i remembered that the hard way.  Overall i rate this 9/10.

Why on earth would I buy a game where you just drive a truck around? How is that even fun?  These are the questions I used to ask myself whenever this game popped up on my Steam store. The only reason I bought it was because it was reduced to around £5 and I wanted to see what all the fuss was about.  I'm glad I did as the game is strangely satisfying. It does what its meant to do very well, it feels genuine, like you're really driving a truck and the environment has been lovingly created, making your journies a cenic delight. When I just want to relax while gaming, I play this. Put the radio on, pick up your cargo, sit back and go for a nice drive across Europe.  The game's only downside is that the AI of other vehicles on the road is sometimes iffy, for example I was caught in a traffic jam once, I'd sat there for about 5 mins waiting for it to move until I decided to drive around the cars in front to find the car at the front of the jam was just sitting there with nothing in front of it.  Great game!

I recommend it... and used to be a truck driver but in North America.  However, I doubt I'll play a whole lot, the game becomes a chore for me very quickly. Steering with a keyboard is probably the biggest hiccup. What I dislike the fact the game is that it's very generic. Once you seen once town you seen them all. It's a fun game if you're looking to kill time, this will kill a lot of it. For me, a 'retired' RL trucker, it started to feel like a job. The pressure to get there early and be on time and the fact that if you take a wrong exist, you're fracked.  On a professional level, a lot of this game is missing that can't really make it a real simulator.  -No circle checks (CC) for trucks (should be at least twice daily pre and post trip) -Most railings way too close to white line -If someone t-bones my trailer, I should be able to fight my ticket -Never have to go to the bathroom, this is a huge factor... soiling yourself could cost you more than a pair of pants -Coffee is missing when in fact, it's the fuel of truckers -Auto Parking should deduct experience - Truckers are experts at backing up and SHOULD be - I used to charge for backing up other's truck -The flashers and marker lights should be a bit more bright -Speed limiter's speeds are set by the company (I drove 55MPH & 62MPH trucks of the same company) -Driver manager distributes the loads accordingly - even Owner Operators often join trucking companies who take O/O's because it's a steady flow of income, instead of waiting in random truck stops to get a load back home but are free to take or refuse any work load they want. -Shunter Drivers - Be one or hire one. Those work either around specific company yards or just do the shunting around town... two different trucks too. Shunters don't leave a trifecta of cities within the same larger megalopolis. -Fueling - Drivers have to get out and fuel -Log Book - We still use paper logs for most part but some companies do have e-logs, also part of CC. -Windows & Washer - Never used them here... it's a very integral part of trucking and is part of CC. -You can never go bankrupt... I tried... ask the millions of O/O's who did though, see what they'll tell ya.  Simulator-wise it's passable, as a realistic trucking game it's a pretty dang good time killer but don't play it if you're mad, play it when you're in the zone.
I think I'm going to become a truck driver from this game. Relaxing and amazing. And people laugh at me when i say i play this game and that i find it fun...

Great gameplay (if you don't mind longish, challenging drivers were you have to balance speed, percision, and the sometimes dodging of other vehicles), and good graphics, and an excellent community of mod'ers from whom you can add almost any feature you want to the game, from more realistic physics to American style trucks to different cargos to economy modifiers where you are either paid more, or less, per load, and even maps for different parts of the world.  Some things I would like to see, though:  1)Fine modifier: Fines increase each tme you get one (except when the car hits you. Why do I get fined when the car switches into my lane and hits my truck???). Also, a time penalty for accidents.  2)Truck modifications and maintenance that take time. Instantaneous engine change, or repairs? I don't think so. Maybe a hire mechanics thing for the garages as well--a few extra staff to pay, but who's skill and number can decrease the amount of time maintenance takes when repairing/maintaining a truck that returns to the garage (not just your personal vehicle, but those of your company drivers as well). 3) Your own trailer--and the need to back up to a loading bay and wait for the cargo to unload. 4) Team drivers: two to a truck.  Lots more I would love to see.   Game runs fairly well on my single core 3.3GHz PC with 1GB video and 2GB Ram on mostly medium and low settings (actually runs better on that than on my 3GHZDual Core Linux with 1GB video card and 4GB Ram)

This is truly a beautiful game. The graphics and physics are so real that sometimes I get in real life fatigue because of it. I ACTUALLY felt like I was driving for hours, but In reality, it was maybe only a half-an-hour. I love the fact that if you don't turn in your 'load' at the right time, there are penalties. I also love the fact that you can CUSTOMISE YOUR TRUCK, and/or buy your own and practically run a functioning company! I am very pleased with this game and will play it whenever i'm 'bored' or 'can't find anything else to play' because this game can act as a boredum-killer or time-consuming game, But it's up to you. One of the things that really stood out in ETS2, is that it has it's own Modding system where you can download and install other people's mods. BUT. You have to be careful. Not all of those 'mods' are safe, some of them are scams- So BE CAREFUL when installing and downloading mods from an unknown website. As I was saying, One of the mods I had tried out and made sure wasn't a scam; Was ETS2:MP (Euro Truck Sim. 2: Multiplayer)! Yes, Multiplayer. I ACTUALLY played with other truckers. It was insanely cool. But be sure it's the official website if you're planning on downloading and installing ETS2:MP. I remember the first time I played this game, man it was fun. And the thing is, I STILL PLAY! Most of the games I happen to play, I can't get an interest grip on, But THIS game? Heck Yeah. Thanks for taking your time in reading this~ I appreciate it!  PROS:  + Graphics Are Great! + Physics Are Realistic! + MODS! + Controls Are Good! + BECOME A COMPANY OWNER! + HIRE WORKERS & BUY/CUSTOMISE TRUCKS! + Can be a time-consumer and/or a boredum-killer + Back-In Your Trailer For Extra EXP! + Import Your Own Music (So you can jam on the roads WHILE being a badass)! + Variety of Different Trucks To Drive! + Not all Trucks Drive The Same! + Can Be Played Online Through A Mod (ETS2:MP)!  CONS:  - Can be laggy because of other cars/truckers/cities - Tunnels are laggy as ♥♥♥♥ (For me, anyways) - Cars can be total idiots and jerks (so can other AI Truckers)... - It can take to 2 to 3 loads to level up one. - Collisions Can Tip You Over. - TRAFFIC AND LAG. - Only Can Be Played Singleplayer UNLESS You Install/Download ETS2:MP. - NOT intended for Computers that can't run extreme (Graphic-wise, though you can lower them) games...  10 Out Of 10, I Will Drive That Truck Again!

Many would never consider playing a game in this category. I know I used to think the same. Spend hours driving trucks from city A to B ? To summarize : hell yeah ! ^^ Driving these trucks around is a relaxing experience, just the kind of game one would need at the end of a full day at work. The graphics are nice, though I would've liked SCS to improve them a bit more (hint : take a look at 'The Crew'). I'd also loved it if the map scale would be a tad smaller (currently around 1:19, maybe 1:15 or even towards 1:10 would've been nice IMO). The AI still does stupid stuff (e.g. jamming you after you pass toll stations or when desperately wanting to enter a pertol station). Nevertheless, SCS continues to patch the game and improve the AI, which is great (version 1.22 at the time of writing this review). Got the 'Going East' DLC and planning to buy the 'Scandinavia' one at the next Steam Sale. The 'High Power Cargo Pack' is a bit light on content though (7 or 8 new cargo types), but I bought it for the added difficulty. Would love to see some additional cargo types added to this DLC in the future, maybe to round it up to 10 or so ... Overall, a 7/10. It's not my kind of game, but I enjoyed playing it more than I'd ever thought I would.

Let me start by saying I am usually not a fan of simulators. At all. I tend to find them lacking in purpose and direction, and can't bring myself to play them more than the opening experience. That being said, it's almost impossible to describe why ETS2 is so enjoyable.  The premise is simple. You pick a job, pick up the trailer, drop off the trailer and collect money and XP. Money goes towards new trucks, equipment, garages and hiring drivers, and XP goes towards unlocking new jobs or increasing rewards (or lowering fuel usage). There's really not much more to it than that, and yet, ETS2 is strangely engaging.  You can approach ETS2 like a genuine simulator, where you obey traffic rules, take a nice, slow pace for jobs, listen to the soothing 'taps' of your indicator and relax along to the gentle hum of your engine. It sounds simple, but it's oddly cathartic. Alternatively, you can haul ♥♥♥, roaring down the highway at breakneck speeds, praying your trailer doesn't tip around the corner as you cut off AI and weave through traffic, racing against fatigue as you listen to jams like 'Convoy' and 'East Bound and Down' (more on this later).  If you're like me, like I know I am, the most you know about trucks is that they're big. And slow. ETS2 lets you jump straight in and drive from A to B simply with WASD, and you can even skip parking the trailer in exchange for an XP loss. Alternatively, for the full truck simulation experience, you can opt to manually control everything from your gear selection to your retarder to your axle height, use of your exhaust brake, and even manually using your mirrors and on-board GPS system instead of the user-friendly HUD elements (you can even adjust your mirrors to suit your needs).  That being said, there are some limitations to the simulator. From what I understand, the physics aren't fully 100% accurate, for things such as being able to use any chassis size for any job and not seeing much of a difference in physics (there may be some) during storms. Speed limits change without warning in some sections (usually just before a speed camera), but these are relatively predictable once you're familiar with an area. AI behaves in strange ways, particularly around roundabouts, so you'll probably end up with a fine for causing a crash because some driver tried to overtake you on the outside. That being said, the AI is often predictable and you can avoid these incidents with a bit of practise.  There is no in-game music (outside of menus) and the radio station requires an internet connection, so you'll have to bring along your own jams for the offline experience. The graphics are starting to show their age, but the sounds are quite authentic. And of course, there is mod support and .ini tweaking to create the experience you desire.  Overall, this is definitely my favourite simulator, and I now look at trucks and truck drivers from a whole new perspective.

All of the non-licenced brands were licenced (Except Volvo) I played the non-steam version for about 200 hours (probably more)alone. I had about a million save games. I played it. Then in December 2013 I took a break from PC games and went to PS3 and XBOX360. But the tie of euro truck simulator couldn't be broken! So in late 2014 I went back to it! Well not really... I had the demo of Euro Truck Simulator 2 at first. My birthday was coming up so I asked for a 20 Pound steam gift card. Then I bought Euro Truck Simulator 2.   So here is my review:   When I first bought Euro Truck Simulator 2 I thought it was great. Driving my truck, Making money, Driving around freely. It was perfect. (I didn't know there was a multiplayer at this time.) Then when I closed Euro Truck Simulator 2 I saw that it said there was a multiplayer. So I downloaded it. (My friend also had multiplayer just didn't tell me.) Once I got it I played Euro Truck Simulator 2 multiplayer and I loved it. But then I played with my friend. Trust me if you play Euro Truck Simulator 2 and you have a friend who has it play Multiplayer. In multiplayer you can join VTC'S (Virtual Trucking Companies) Which is where you can Join companies and work for them. You can join there Teamspeak, Join special events which is good and it's just amazing.   Overall I rate this game 10/10, This game is for the people who like A Money Making, Real life game. If you do then this is definetly the game for you. If you next buy a game on steam I recommend for you to buy this game.

I've watched XBoxAhoy play this game several times in his YouTube videos and finally decided to give it a try. I'm glad I did because it's highly addictive. I was worried that it would be in real time and you'd be sinking literal hours into the game for one single trip, but with time compression, it makes the gameplay fun and quick. 300km trips typically take around 10-15 minutes to complete, with longer trips obviously taking, well... longer. I got this game on the holiday sale, so it was a great bargain, but knowning now what I know, I would recommend buying at full price.

I feel like you know before you buy this whether or not it would be something that interests you. Do you want to drive a semi/lorry in a realistic environment? Do you want to drive on the wrong side of the road... take a ferry across the channel... and then drive on the right side? Do you want to get a ticket for going 4 mph over the speed limit because you didn't see that speed limit sign and downshift quick enough? Do you want to turn your blinker on, look both ways, and then have traffic respond accordingly and then swing it wide? And more importantly, do you want to back up a trailer into a tight space and get extra cash for doing so... cash which you can use to put extra mirrors/lights/side-skirts or horns on your rig? Then this game is for you.  10/10, would swing it wide again     Side note - I'll soon be investing in a wheel/pedal/knob combo soon... I'll update my review after truly experiencing the game :)

I bought ETS2 because it was on sale...and then I drove deliveries for two hours between Venezia, Milano, and Zurich. The crazy part is that I actually loved playing this game...it is like the driving simulator I always dreamed about! The highways are EXACTLY like what I remembered when I went to Italy, the handling & driving is easy to get used to with gamepad (I use a DualShock 3 with MotionInJoy), and the first few missions are simple and fun.  If you are looking for driving zen, a game where you can just chill and listen to your favorite music or podcast while doing a stress-less (but not with a lack of difficulty) task, then this is your game.  EDIT 12/13/14: after putting substantially more time into this game, I have to add even more praise into my review! This game has one of the best open world designs I have ever seen in any game. I actually use the picture mode in the game for taking pictures as if I am sightseeing and there are times when I have to Wiki an area that isn't a playable town because it looks so cool (like Bregenz). Some games do not get the recognition they deserve and this is one of them...

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is, as the name states, a game where you drive European trucks around Europe and the UK. It is suprisingly calming and fun, unlike some other simulators. There is a wide range of vehicles for you to chose from.  PROS: Massive map (2-4 hours from left to right, depending on your truck's top speed). Real truck brands with realistic sounds and high quality models (Except Mercedes, there is lisencing issues there). Graphics are really nice. AI is ok, could use some improving. There is a great multiplayer mod. And a huge modding community.  CONS: Keyboard driving isn't to good, a steering wheel is recomended, or even just an xbox controller (I use a Logitech Driving Force GT).

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is that rare thing, a strong sim tethered to a strong game. Where other vehicle-obsessed devs seem to take player motivation for granted, Czech studio SCS understand that a pleasingly modelled steed needs a pleasingly modelled environment to shine.  On this occasion that environment is a swathe of Europe stretching from Plymouth in the west to Wroclaw in the east, from Aberdeen in the north to Milan in the South. The tangle of motorways and major roads is stylised and condensed, but feels massive. After a splendid week of non-stop trucking the stats screen tells me I've still only seen 50% of it.  There's satisfaction in exploring new routes, seeing new golden been-there-done-that squiggles appearing on the in-game map, but it tends to be the promise of cold, hard cash that gets you out of bed in the morning. Like Farming Simulator, ETS2 has a simple yet resonant economic sandbox at its centre.  You start as a low-skilled, truckless lorry jockey, forced to take work from established haulage companies. Slowly (or rapidly if you go to a bank) you amass the funds to buy your first rig and rent your first yard. Then the fun really begins. Contract perusing, truck pimping, skill upgrading, driver hiring... this is Eddie Stobart: The Game in all but name.  Spending 90 minutes ferrying a tank of propane from Sheffield to Prague could (should?) be tedious. The fact that it isn't is largely down to good-if-not-quite-OMSI-standard physics, and varied road layouts and scenery. Periods of smooth, almost soporific motorway motoring nestle between passages of edgier wheelwork. One minute you're cruising along contemplating the sunset over the central reservation, the next you're on a rain-lashed country road at night, waiting for the right moment to pass a painfully slow pantechnicon. Tiredness can't kill in ETS2, but it can leave you jack-knifed in a ditch, feeling awful with a substantial repair bill to pay.

If you want to drive very aggressively you can turn fines and speed limiter off. There's no win state and you have to crash constantly to actually lose, but there's still a challenge in growing your business and aquiring better trucks. As for the Linux version, everything works except for the radio feature.

This is one Game / Simulator that can captivate you for hours. The greatest feature in my opinion, is that there is a lot of add ons, generally called mods. One way to get them is to download the content from the internet. Another way is to customize your vehicle, trailer, etc yourself. The latter requires some learning and understanding. With a few other free tools from the internet, you are armed to take on these task's.  The realism of the Graphics is stunning, the whole works is putting you in the cockpit of a 38 Ton european semi truck that gives you the impression to really pilot one of these Monsters. Would have been nice to also have a tractor - trailer config, but the 'Sattel Aufleger' will do too. I guess this is the trend with modern 'Fracht Transport Firmen' anyway. Has it's advantages, I have to admit. Also, I recommend a Logitech Steering Wheel, unfortunately at a cost. I had an older one sitting in the closet for years, so I didn't have to spent on that. With the Steering wheel, shifter and pedals, it is much smoother to control and in my opinion adding to the all over experience. There is a position sensing device, that tracks your head movements and moves the cabin view to the position you are looking at, maybe some day. Recent talk is about Multi Player Mods, which seems to be tempting, but it is only in a Public Alpha state. We'll keep an eye on that too.

If you are interested in driving, like me, or are interested in running a buisness related to driving car or truck, then this game is for you. Overall the game mechanics are great, each job pays well enough to make you want to keep playing but doesnt pay enough to make the game too easy. You really get attached to the trucks you buy, you invest time and money into your buisness and your trucks.  The buisness owning aspect of the game is fantastic, you can plan to start a company asap by taking out a loan, or you can save up for a while to avoid being in debt, there is so many possibilities. The graphics are great, The driving mechanic is litterally flawless and this game is as close as you can get to the real thing.  However this game does have minor issues. The A.I. is very wacky, sometimes getting you into an extremely costly accident making your 1 hour journey worthless. There is no visible damge on the trucks, so you can crash head on into a barrier and your truck would look brand new. The only other problem is if you are a new player, the frequent fines can really drain your bank account.  Overall I love this game, you should too, What are you waiting for?

It is hard to explain what makes this game so addicting. On paper it looks like the most boring thing in the world. Driving a truck from one city to another for hours, but like Civilization has its 'just one more turn' this game has a similar thing. Just a little further, just get to the next city, just one more one more trip.  I don't really have any interest in trucks, but I have still put alot of hours into this game. Both relaxing and rewarding. You level up with each trip, so there is a good sense of progression and even a basic RPG element as well. With many other games today having a very open world and tons of possibilities, there is something appealing about something utterly simple like getting from point A to point B. No real choices or stragies to make, just do it. Probably not a thing for everybody, but give it a try even though it looks boring on paper.

Euro Truck Simulator is a strange game in that it shouldn’t be as popular as it is. SCS software have managed to craft something that is something that few games can claim. A genuinely relaxing experience. The game includes support for streaming radio and it is quite relaxing to simply drive for 20 minutes across europe listening to your preferred radio station. The game keeps track of things like speeding and the correct operation lights and turning signals so there is a feeling of achievement when you arrive at your destination without penalty. The game boasts a RPG like levelling system and the ability to buy trucks, customize them and hire NPC drivers.

I love this game. Whenever I'm perusing my list of games, and I can't find one, I load up this game, and play. Its exactly what it sounds, trucking across Europe, and they do it right. You create your trucking company, select you 'endgame' truck, and proceed to start the reign of your trucking company. You are given a truck from companys for your first missions, and once you can afford your own truck (usually runs from [selected currency]99,000- 110,000) you can start either roaming across Europe in your truck, or find a job, and drive your truck to that country. After that point, you just truck, level up, and increasethe size of your company, and slowly become the primary trucking company in Europe.

One of the most addictive games I've played yet. It's so engrossing to sit back with your mouse and keyboard while listening to a podcast or the radio or other things like that. The trucks are varied and contain a mountain of customisation options. The AI traffic is generally ok, with a recent patch enhancing it further.  The only weakness is in managing your own truck company, this isn't very rewarding. You don't see your trucks on the road and only really see them earning you money.  So if you're looking for a relaxing driving simulator to take you across a continent this is definitely the game for you and at less than £20 it's great value.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a truck simulation game created by SCS Software, using OpenGL. It is the sequel to Euro Truck Simulator, with a redone physics and game engine. The player can drive across a significant part of Europe. Player should pick up a variety of cargoes, and delivering them to the desired destination. The game features 8 different trucks, includes: DAF, Volvo, Man, Scania, Renault, M. Benz and Iveco. 4 of them are licensed already.  Gameplay You can start your game in one of the following countries: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. You will be asked to select your desired city in one of them. Your garage will be located there. So the journey will be begin. In the beginning, you wont have enough money and experience to buy a truck, so you will start with quick deliveries. You also can get loans. You can open your own company, hiring drivers from all over the map. What you need is to have enough money to afford their trucks purchase and a free slot in a garage. You can buy a garage in every city you tend, Then you should upgrade it.  The gameplay is so sweet and handy. Its obvious how the developers have worked on it. and they have done it nicely. Riding trucks seems so realistic with a great system of handling. So after delivering any cargo, you will be given an amount of money and EXP will be gained. EXP is needed to unlock trucks and items. As you gain an amount of EXP, you earn a level as well. You also will be estimated as your level in the game. The system of opening of company makes a motivation for the player. Its almost the goal of the game. AI of the vehicles in ETS 2 is actually OK. its average, but they are making it better with every patch to make the game an awesome experience for the player. Accidents are not so realistic. Plus you wont get any physical damage. After any accident your truck will be damaged, but not physically. actually nothing happens to your truck. Its a defect. The game physic is good and its being improved by every patch.  You wont see any police in the game. But there are traffic lights, speed limit, toll stops and accident penalty. if you violate any mentioned things [except toll], you should pay an specific amount of fine. This systems made without any defect. The driver will become tired, so you should pull over in an specific place to get rest. Gas stations, repair stations, drivers agencies, Truck showplaces and resting stations are available in the game. For buying a truck, you need to visit its shop [which are in its own particular city] or you can use online purchasing. Any truck needs a slot in your garage. The limitation of slots is 5 in per garage. Also drivers you can hire are limited at 116 at the moment. Overall, this part of the game is decent. except some defects like lack of physical damages. Also the map is so much big. thats a fantastic point. so much to explore with a great system of running company that let you enjoy the title for many days.   Graphic The graphics are stunning. Lighting system and shadows are awesome. Vegetables, trees and environments made perfectly. Designing of trucks is amazing. Into the cabin has very good details with a perfect designing. But designing cities are kinda average. You also can see humans in the cities. There are also some famous places made in the game. Cargoes have a good variety. Weather system is great. Raining seems so realistic. You can enjoy the darkness of the night, the sunset, the sunrise and the sunlight in the middle of the noon. Also Other vehicles seem average. This part is one of the most important factors that makes this simulator so special, and puts it as the best truck simulator ever made.  Sound Well, the sound effects part is nothing special. I cant really talk about this. The sound seems so low when you are into the cabin camera. You should switch to another camera mode to hear it better. Its overall made well. There is also online radio streaming. Its decent. Also you can make your customized track list from your own music library.

5* A lot of fun, makes you feel you're really in control of a HGV, I usually just stick to the UK jobs, but travelling over to the East had its benefits, the scenery is amazing, and you get a real sence of pleasure when you complete a job :) If you like your simulators, you'll love this!! I highly recommend

I've never been much of a fan of driving games. In fact, the games I own that involve driving are games like GTA, Sleeping Dogs, Just Cause Etc. So naturally I didn't expect to enjoy this game, however I gave it a shot. And boy was I wrong! The idea of doing nothing but drive around Europe in a legal manner is not something I would think of ever enjoying, but I can't stop playing! Instead of opening AC IV, Deus Ex or Dishonoured, I find myself lying back on the chair, feet up, controller in hand, listening to foreign radio stations while driving down a highway in France, or down an alleyway in Germany. There truely is something magical about this game that I cannot explain, but all I can say is get it. If you like driving games, get it. If you don't like driving games, get it. If you like Trucks, get it. If you - well, you get the point. Just get it! Or atleast get the demo and experience it yourself. You (hopefully) won't regret it! :)

A surprisingly fun game. It's a fun and realistic game all around, with only a few problems. The main one is the stupidity of the AI, but this will be fixed in the coming update. Another thing which annoys me personally is the inaccuracy of junctions, which are nothing like they are in real life, but otherwise the roads are very realistic. At the moment, the game is also incompatible with Intel cards on Linux, which is kind of annoying.  Throughout the UK and other countries you can see landmarks which are the same as in real life and for example, the ratio of motorways to smaller roads in Poland feels accurate. Cities also feel realistic, with some real life features being added to give a specific feel to every city. For example, you can see the local city hall in the background as you drive through Olsztyn.  With the Going East! DLC installed, there's a wide variety of places you can go. There's also a variety of mods which add more features to the game if you get bored.  It's clear that there are more features the developer can add to the game in the future (it is frequently updated), but it doesn't feel repetetive.
