I love game like this, and have Euro Truck Sim and UK Truck Sim already. This isn't a blending of the two, it's much more.  They've really impressed me with this game...with all the extra stuff they've added. It took me a while to get the hang of the new steering system, but once I did I found it to be much easier and less jerky than before.  It's much more realistic, and I've even seen pedestrians in this game. I just saw a jumbo jet land as I was driving down the motorway.  They've added many more ferry services, toll roads and even level crossings. I thought they were just decoration but nope, I saw a train earier with the barrier and lights and everything.  Customisation is a great addition, although the extra lights don't really help unless you have high beams on, and the other drivers don't like that...flashing me when I'm using them.  The AI has been improved too. For example, in Euro Truck SIm 1, if there was a blockage of any kind, the AI cars just sat there with their hazard lights flashing. If you were behind them, you had to find an alternate route, ot barge through...bad idea. This time, the AI doesn't just sit there. I'll give you a quick example. I was coming up to a junction, and saw a lot of stationary traffic. Yep, blockage. There was a bus trying to turn left, but a truck was trying to turn right and they'd kinda blocked each other. The other road had cars trying to go but this bus was stopping things. I thought I was gonna have to drive round, but nope...I was shocked to see the bus actually reversing into a better turning position, turn then drive on it's way. The truck then did the same, turning into the right road...end of blockage and all was well.  The AI even wait at the on-ramps for it to become clear, and even go into the petrol stations now. It's much more realistic and enjoyable.  Although, the AI isn't perfect. Right of way is still a mystery to them. I was driving down a main street, and the cars on either side of the junction should've waited for me to pass before driving out, but nope...at the last moment a truck came out and I couldn't avoid it. That's the only bad thing I can say about this game...but if you know about it, you can avoid it.  9/10 rating from me because of the little flaws (lights and AI), but other than that I'm really enjoying this game.

So this game sounds really stupid, right? Sounds like just driving trucks around? Well, that's totally what it is. However, its a lot more fun than it originally sounds, and for some reason, it's kept me coming back for more.  When you first start the game, you are asked to create a company for your trucking business. When you start, you don't have enough capital or credit to take out a loan, so you just take 'quick missions' running freight from European city to city. This serves as a pretty good introduction to the game, and allows you to get a good feel for how the game plays. This is what drew me in. I had a lot more fun than you'd expect attaching the back of the trailer to the truck and driving it around the roads. There's not much actual city driving, as the cities themselves are pretty small. But that's okay. As I found out one day, I really am not playing this game to sit in traffic, so if there was just a bunch of city with cars, I don't think I'd like it very much. Sure, it would be more 'real', but sometimes you should sacrifice reality for fun.  After you get the trailer hitched up, you roll out of the industrial park you picked it up in and get on the road. This game doesn't work with a controller, as there are too many buttons to push to fit on a controller. You need to use you turn indicators, check your mirrors and change your views. You need to drive inside the lines, not hit other cars, and generally just obey all traffic laws. Again, this sounds really boring, but when you finally get to your destination, and you haven't hit anyone, its pretty rewarding. It also helps most cars drive faster than you, so you don’t have to play that annoying weaving game of trying to pass cars because they drive 20 MPH below the speed limit.   When you get enough capital, you can take out a loan and buy your own truck. The trucks they have for sale are all real trucks, and all have different stats and strengths. You then can take missions for your business and every mission has advantages and disadvantages (eg, the dangerous cargo gives you the most money). Every mission your complete (quick job or company mission) gives you experience and level up various stats, such as levels of dangerous cargo, increased fuel efficiency, and increased money for each mission. I haven’t got too far into the business side of the game, but I hear you can hire other drivers to work for you.  Overall, I enjoy this game thoroughly. For some reason, it’s compelling to come back just drive by the trees and fields of Europe, even if they're not the real thing.

9.5/10  I would definitely recommend this game, If you love driving simulators then this is the choice for you. I don't own a steering wheel it would be nice to own one though. But for me the keyboard does the job. I enjoy just relaxing and driving around completing jobs in this game. Really fun.

The most addicive driving game ever. You basically drive trucks and manage your bussiness.  You start off by making a company, then pick your preffered type of truck, I chose Volvo. Then off you go driving borrowed trucks for companies during deliveries, it's either that til you can afford your own truck, or borrow money from the bank.  later in the game you drive to the companies to do deliveries in your own trucks, there are a couple types of deliveries; fragile cargo, dangerous cargo, valuable cargo, and short time deliveries. You have to upgrade your skills to get the more valuable ones and to get deliveries with further distances.  You can upgrade your base of operations and purchase more of them, you can hire managers and drivers, you also have to purchase trucks for your drivers. I'm not that far into the game though, I've got a pimped up truck and little cash left, and at around 30 hours it's still not getting boring yet!  Got a gaming wheel? Excellent! Much more fun with a gaming wheel. although it doesn't seem to have full compatibility yet, i ended up turning the sensitivity for turning up to full. It doesn't seem to have much support for force feedback either, but it's still pretty fun. Oh, and did i mention it works with gears? Thats right, with the G27 or similar gaming wheel, you have a gear case thingy! You can choose between the increadibly difficult advanced gearing system based on the real manual trucks, or the normal H configuration you'll find in most cars. by the way, i hope you know how to pop a clutch, this game supports that.  I recommend picking this game up on steam when it's on sale though, since there's only a couple months left til the holidays. Did i forget anything? Anyway, let's hope they update their support for gaming wheels!

Euro Truck Simulator 2.  What can be said about this game that hasn't been said already. It is quite fun to play. I have approximately 20 hours in the game, and that's about where I'd say most users that would be interested in this, would get to. For someone more casual, and not into the 'sim' genre (think... the person that plays flight simulator, and the first thing they do is nose it over into the ground because they wanted to see what the crash looked like)... you're probably looking at about 5 hours.  Pros: The game is good, it's well oiled, and a complete package. You'll have no problem picking it up, driving for miles, and running an RPG style trucking company if you'd like, or you could simply roam about in the countryside racking up speeding fines.  Cons: They types of loads get a bit repetitive, and I think the developers are missing a HUGE opportunity for a CHALLENGING trucking sim. Spin Tires goes further than it needs to (though still a FANTASTIC game), but where Spin Tires is all mud, and challenge... ETS2 is all highway, and cruise control. Adding a variety of loads to carry, and the challenge of mountain trucking, or big city fuel tanker deliveries, etc... would make this game much more interesting.  Still, the mod community is strong. I prefer not to mod, since they're largely just skins, which I find provide nothing more than (no pun) a skin deep experience.  Buy it if: You're fascinated by running a freight business as an owner/operator, and enjoy the long haul aspects of FSX.  Skip it if: You're looking for something that requires you to think your way through something, or do more than remember to indicate properly, and back a big rig into a loading dock. True story, I've fallen asleep while driving on the virtual highway on a longhaul... which is probably realistic... but not the kind of realism I want in a game.  I'm giving it a 7/10 if you don't mod. I wish there was more variety in the challenge of loads (long loads, doubles, triples, oversized, etc.), and the traffic AI seems to leave something to be desired.

Yes, it's nerdy.   Yes, it's just driving a truck from A to B.   However, if you are looking for something unique that isn't dealing death to millions of identikit villains or being a one-person saviour of the universe, why not give Euro Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) a try?  I recently moved from Xbox 360 back to the PC scene. In the years that I had an Xbox, I found that I really missed the kind of games that only PC has. Games where essentially nothing happens. The world won't end if you don't achieve your objective.  This is why I like ETS2.  This is an extremely well-supported game. The publishers regularly issue free updates (not just bug fixes, but additional cities, road networks, trucks, etc).   I have sunk hours into this game just driving a truck from one city to another, and then another city, etc. It is a great way to while away time with no stress. Although the roads and cities are very loosely based on the real-life versions, I don't think that you could ever hope to compare game vs. real-world with any degree of accuracy. Having said that, there are certain roads that I have travelled in-game and in real-life and found myself thinking 'wow, they got that right!', so must be an element of consideration of the real-world road network.  Controls were initially an issue, but a recent update fixed that with proper Xbox controller support. Performance-wise, the game has never crashed or had any technical problems at all. It runs at max settings on my PC (which is fairly high-spec, so I would expect that!)  My main criticisms are minor; the graphics can seem a little bleached out / over-saturated (in HDR mode especially), sometimes the AI drivers create a bottleneck where they all block a junction waiting for a vehicle to turn - this causes the lane that the vehicle needs to cross to become blocked (I had to barge my way through the roadside to get past!). Another minor complaint is that the roads seem very under-populated. If possible, there needs to be an option to increase AI traffic.  All in all, I love ETS2 and would recommend it to anyone looking for a game to pass time in.

This was recommended by a friend and I got it in the recent Steam sale. I thought it would be boring but it is insanely addictive. It is a simple concept: drive from one city to another in the time allowed and try not to crash. It is introduced very well as well. Once you have created your company in the menus you can take on quick jobs that provide you with a truck and all of your fuel is paid for. Then once you've earned enough money you can buy your own truck and drive freely to any location on the map. You are constantly gaining experience points that make jobs payout more. You can upgrade certain skills that unlock bigger cargos to haul around. There are quite a few choices of trucks to buy.  The is being updated regularly and new features are always fun to play with. A recent update gave you three extra cities to drive to at no extra cost which I thought was pretty special. The only dissapointment with the game is that there are no complete cities to explore. When you come off the motorway you have access to a series of roads connecting the different company depots, repair stations and truck dealers.  I would recommend this game to anyone who likes driving games but wants a change from racing. This is more of an endurance driving simulator when you unlock the longest routes.

Absolutely amazing! The game takes you across Europe, from Hungary all the way to United Kingdom (if you have the Going East DLC), giving you the opportunity to put yourself in the shoes of a modern trucker. You have a huge road network to drive on and a rich collection of trucks which you can configure in a myriad of ways - from cabin style to wheels and accessories. Beside that, you have the possibility to easily mod the game to use third party trucks, trailers, AI, weather, even entirely new map mods. And if this is not enough there is also a multiplayer mod which is absolutely free to use, made by a passionate community group of modders. Graphics are astonishing and sometimes the views you encounter are just amazing. Phisics are pretty good although they could be further improved. Real truck drivers I have talked to, who are playing the game, said the trucks behave close to real ones and are pretty accurate.  On the negative side I believe the AI is the thing that still needs improvements, though it has been overhauled recently. Things like not giving way at some roundabouts and just driving into you or not keeping the distance when you try to maneuver in tight intersections should be addressed. But I'm sure most of us forget about these things when driving on highways or country roads, with the radio on and the turbocharger whistling at you when you press the accelerator.  Overall, a really great game for those who love driving in a realistic manner.

Unexpectedly fun.  When I first heard all the rave about this game and people saying how great it was, I thought it was all a big joke and that everyone was being sarcastic. Turns out I was wrong.  This game is essentially a brilliant simulator, the dev's struck a perfect balance between realistic and fun, but you can also turn certain mechanics on or off to customise the experience. Steering wheel support is great too!  The game simply involves your journey as a truck driver, start of hiring your skills out to other companies , until you can afford a truck of your own, then strike out to build your empire, hire drivers, buy more trucks and garages , get rich!  You can customise your truck and all the options to play exactly how you want , things like realism of fuel usage , driver fatigue, probability of rain etc. can all be adjusted, you are penalised for being caught speeding, crashing, driving the wrong way up roads etc. all in all its pretty damn good fun , allot more so with a steering wheel and pedals.  I'll end my saying the game has a s**t tonne of content, Im 20 hours in and Ive only just paid off the bank loan I took out to buy my own truck, all the drivers, garages, better trucks, modifications, I havent even scratched the surface.......

Oddly engaging and meditative. You drive a truck around Europe (well, a greatly reduced imitation of Europe) delivering all sorts of random goods, level your driver up, then head out to deliver more stuff. That's pretty much all there is to it. On the surface it sounds incredibly boring and like something that would only appeal to a niche audience, but oddly enough it works. While the game can be modded to satisfy the hardcore sim fan, the vanilla game is very simple and not at all the kind of in-depth driving sim you might expect. Once you get used to the controls, driving becomes much easier and eventually you're just sort of 'in the zone.' Listen to a podcast or an audio book. Just chill. really if I had any complaints about the game it's that there are no in-game guides of any kind on what exactly certain traffic laws are in certain places, so there are occasions where you may find yourself getting tickets for things you weren't expecting. Maybe this is a glitch, but it seems like driving around central Europe you would have to be a psychopath to get a fine, but the second you set foot (or in this case, set tire) in Britain, you get speeding and lane-change fines up the ♥♥♥♥, yet it is not entirely clear what limits you are breaking. The only future improvements I would like to see would be maybe tuning up the NPC car AI?

In these days of bad German simulators, European Truck Simulator 2 is a breath of fresh air. From the moment you load it up, you are greeted with a beautiful world. When you start to drive the trucks, you can really feel the weight and power that I imagine it must feel like to be a truck driver. The modelling of not only the trucks, but also the AI cars is outstanding. The sounds are almost spot on. The roads offer differing degrees of difficulty. You can imagine you are really behind the wheel of your favourite truck, whether it be Scania, MAN or Volvo, or one of the other trucks in the game. The design of the menu system is beautiful and simplistic. It is easy to use. The addition of a mod menu is another plus, even though SCS Software does not support them. There are many mods out there but I definitely recommend the Jazzycat Trailer mods. The world is absolutely gorgeous if you are fortunate enough to be able to run it at high settings. The only down side to this game (I feel) is that, in my opinion, there isn't enough road. So if you are a trucker at heart, I recommend this game. It is constantly being fixed and worked on, and you are usually lucky enough to find it on sale. So load up and get on the road! Happy trucking!

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a unbelieveibly Big game and has so much detail and I believe is the best simulator ever made. Other simulators tend to have terrible graphics, a rubbish physics engine and awful gameplay; Euro Truck Simulator 2 is has none of those. The Trucks feel and drive like trucks and you can build a huge trucking empire, It's insane! The Graphics look outstanding even on my rubbish laptop and it runs so smooth. You will never played a true simulator until you've played this. My only problem is that the AI in the other vechicles will ocassionaly break the law and almost kill your truck you've spent hours saving money for. Although that is what it'll be like in REAL LIFE but it happens a bit to often. You need to play this Game!

Seriously, I have no idea why I like this game.  But I do.  I got it as part of some bundle. Then couple weeks later, I though 'let's play this for a few hours, then I probably put it into steam category 'trash'. Well after few hours playing this I played another few. And another few. And... you get it.   * Graphics is nice, but not astonishing, although I like the weather effects from clouds to sun shafts at the horizon. * Sounds are ok I guess (did not drive a tuck myself, though ;) ). And I like the real radio you can use ingame. * Controls are very good! You cannot just use nearly every controller and set everything to anything - but I even attached 2 XBox controllers which can be configured completely seperately - this way I don't have to use the keyboard at all while playing on the couch! Dont know any other game which can do this. * AI is fine, too. Reacts to line change and turn signals, slows down if you do. Sometimes can really suck if no one lets you pass the crossing ;) * Game mechanics for a relatively simple simlulator are good, too. Apart from driving around you can also manage several garages, nearly every town has one you can buy. Still you're mostly driving around, but I think it's a nice motivation for in between to manage garages and hired drivers :) * Also you can modify your truck; choose engine, extra lights, sun block etc. And you can give it nice extra paint jobs with totally custom colors. (And don't buy the color DLCs, in my opinion they're not worth it >.> ) * Still gets patched; after the Scandinavia DLC, performance went downhill in several areas, but couple of weeks later that got fixed.   As I have no clue, why I actually like this, I cannot say 'buy this, if you like... '. But if you got a controller/wheel, you might give it a try; the base game gets pretty cheap in sales anyway, so that would be a nice stop to try it.    PS: All trucks beside Scania and Volvo suck :D

If you enjoy simulators this game is pure FUN! It has a great feeling of European trucking, lots of options to customize your experience depending on what controls do you like, straightforward mechanics and great features to make the game enjoyable whether you're skilled or not (for ex. automatic parking which is a BLESSING here, it's more difficult to control the truck than it was in Haulin or Long Haul or other previous games). The game looks great, gives you easy access to online radios and the world is just perfect. I really like truck customization too!   The only problems that I have in the game are overpriced DLC's (map packs are ok but those paint jobs are ridiculous) amd game crashing on Steam (tested on Windows 7 and Windows 8).

Goergous progress if you start looking to the company progression since 18 Wheels of Steels Pedal of Metal, Haulin and American Long Haul. When I was playing those games, I wouldn`t imagined that company going to be bigger and release a game like Euro Truck Simulator 2 !   The first disapointment when I played 18 Wos: American Long Haul after 18:WOS Haulin, because it was the same game and the only difference was brand new a truck, new 2 or 3 cities and women drivers. There was no patches and updates...  Well, then, they made ETS, which is first euro truck. And it was another map and different trucks, I really liked it. Then they made those 2 games which shows company is growing which are Trucks and Trailers and Scania Truck Driving Simulator... Me and my enviroment was knew these two games are just games like demo and to make budget for actual game which is Euro Truck Simulator 2. I played those games too and after Scania Truck Driving Simulator, I got excited about ETS2.  They released ETS2. Map was good, there was many bugs and many of trucks was not official such as Volvo, Mercedes etc... Then they start updating almost every week. And game extremely developed. Current situation of game is like another game if you consider with first ETS2.  All trucks are official and with real names and logos. Map is quite big and it has many things that makes you feel you are driving a real truck. You can set your seat, mirrors, you can use retarder to slow down and you can lift up/down your wheels if you are not carrying anything. With the DLC`s it is an amazing game, and you can download billions of mods for this game...   Major DLC`s are map DLC`s. If you are going to buy with DLC`s I strongly recommend buy with Scandinavia DLC and Going East.   The best developers and best game I have ever seen in my life. Many of games on Steam are abondoned games by developers. But this game is alive and still keeps developing !

This game is fantastic for relaxation. During the evening after a long day at work, there's no more tranquil activity than rolling around the roads undertaking a little digital sightseeing and completing the gentle objectives of delivering loads. This game has a truly extensive modding community, which really transforms the base game into an incredibly large and diverse map, with some map mods boasting really good attention to detail. There are also a plethora of different trucks and trailers, weather, lighting, and other mods just to give you some more diversity.  You will be surprised just how engaging it is to complete these journeys across such a large network of roads, and find yourself merrily ticking along through some interesting re-creations of European scenery.

This game is a real sleeper. In my case, a Volvo Sleeper. Well, 87 Volvo Sleepers to date to be honest, with 86 drivers hauling freight all over the EU and surronding countries, with MY company name associated with their on-time and under-budget deliveries. That leaves one 750 hp monster for me to pull large, heavy loads at high speeds all over the land (and you'd better hope I remember which side of the road to drive on, lest you meet 30 tons of high speed steel head on). Oh yeah, did I mention that those 86 drivers are dumping their profits into MY company account? That has allowed me to buy and operate 17 garages all over the place (and still looking at where to expand next).  All of that aside, this game is the one I fire up for a few minutes, to play something fun and calm when I get burned out from killing bandits/orcs/enemy soldiers/zombies/etc... What I find amusing is that those few minutes usually end up being 5-10 hours due to grabbing 'just one more run'. The driving is that much fun for me.  The game is worth the MSRP, and is a real steal when on sale, and the DLC is very reasonably priced. Get it. You won't be disappointed. Oh, yeah... You can go out and buy a pricy wheel and pedal set if you want, but I play with mouse and keyboard and do just fine, thank you.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 may as a joke to many gamers but it goes without saying that this is by far one of the best games I've played this year and here's why: The game is extremely vast and enjoyable, I was quickly fascinated by all the detail that the developers have implemented in this simulator. The fact that you can create your own lifestyle as a trucker and have your own company grows on you quite quickly.  What I enjoy mostly about this game and that makes it extremely unique is the fact that you can put your own music into the Document file of this game and simply hit the radio with your favorite songs and relax to the awesome scenery that this game offers 9.3/10 - Simply astonishing.

I 'technically' played ETS 2 long before American Truck Simulator, but I had only tried the beginning tutorial and then promptly forgot about it. Since I enjoyed ATS so much I thought I would give this game a second chance.   While playing ETS you get a much better feeling of scale since it covers much more area than the American version currently and that it is scaled at 1:19 versus 1:34 for ATS. What this means is that if you take a job that requires you to drive from one end of the map to the other you better be prepared to sit awhile. Another change is if you don't live in Europe the road system in ETS may feel similar, but different. If you have never had any experience with roundabouts or driving an English vehicle from the right hand side then ETS will give you the opportunity to see if you can handle it while carrying tons of cargo.  A few complaints that I had in ATS do carry over to ETS2. There is no visual damage model which for me seems very odd for a driving sim with big trucks, but it is what it is I guess. Also what can hurt your truck is very annoying at times. Heaven forbid you hit a small wooden fence while trying to make a turn because not only is it going to damage your truck, but it also is going not move an inch. The driver AI can be a tad crazy or downright suicidal depending on the situation. I've seen AI cars merge in front of trucks and then hard break while on the highway when there was no reason to do so.  In short if you already like ATS or you have ever wanted to drive around a very nice 'mini' version of central Europe then give ETS2 a try. If you end up enjoying the game be sure to try out some of the great mods out there such as Pro Mods.

Do you like trucking? Yes? THIS IS THE GAME FOR YOU! I find this game to be the best trucking simulator that you can find. It takes place in Europe but as long as you don't enter the UK then the experience is the same as a North American sim, in other words there's still the tiny little cars that will cut you off even though you're already speeding. The game allows expansion to many garages(you start with one) and you can upgrade each one along with the trucks you own, eventually hiring drivers to drive one of your trucks and bring in money for you. Eventually you can have drivers everywhere raking in more money than you can handle and you can either keep on driving or sit back and crash cars to spend the money you probably won't need on repairs because you're bored and crashing cars is something to do. There is a multiplayer mod in progress and it absolutely changes the game, especially when you can be trucking with your friends in a convoy. AMAZING GAME.

The best simulator game!!

This sim is a must for any truck lover - whether you're an actual truck finatic or just interested in knowing what it's like to drag 20t of cargo across the continent.  With this sim, you'll experience whether patters, speed cameras, fines for not abiding to driving regulation laws (not sleeping or not turning on your lights), and other annoying things like a fine for crashing into another motorist, and penalty deductions at the end of your trip for damaging the cargo.  You can also modify your truck through the dealers, selecting different trims, lights, horns, bull bars etc for your truck, each manufacturer has a wide selection of vehicles available, not all at once though, you'll have to level up for the hugh powerplant you want.  Not forgetting you can hire staff, buy them trucks to driver, make sure you go for the stat level you can afford as their price per mile differs at their current skill level, go for someone low and it'll take a while for them to level up nicely but when they do you'll get some real $$$, but beware, go for a higher level person for the cash to be brought in now, and you'll find later on they probably arent someone you're going to keep on the books.  In my experience it can sometimes get a little tiring, if you slip up at the end of the journey and have a HUGH crash, that 1200mile trip was pretty much worthless or even cost you money.  Over all I quite like this game, nearly even love it - managing my own truck, my business with staff and stats to manage is right up my street, I can decide to play business man for an hour or simply get in my truck, pick a job and drive - if this sounds like you, then get this game.

Great graphics, poor in road conditions, as where there is a overpass or service station the road has step up. Hate to be driving in real life on those roads as it would be like driving over speed bumps at 70 - 90 kms/hour, not good on suspension. Another bug is the cars that past they then cut one off and the 8 times out of 10 they place the brakes on. No person in real life would do that in front of semi trailers, at what ever speed. The game I is very adictive, well I think so, but I have always liked to drive even in reality. Pity that the makers of the game don't iron out the bugs properly as the humps in the roads (speed humps). The first patch for Going East was great, it ironed out the humps in the road from the original game, but can't install it due to it being obsolete. The extra DLC's in road they are great, but then again those bumps in the main roads are still there. some are worst than others.

I thought this game would be the most boring thing ever. Then watching an old Keralis series on YouTube it got me intrigued. Since the Winter sale was on, I got the Deluxe pack for insanely cheap. As soon as I started I knew I was hooked, I don't have a wheel but it works really well with a 360 controller.  There's really no way to describe WHY the game is fun, you just have to try it out. I find it super relaxing and can listen to radio streams, my music, podcasts etc. Plus SCS seems to be constantly working on improving the game, be it the DLC, getting the real truck licences, adding the World of Trucks website (which has me hooked on Photo Mode like Gran Turismo 4 did back in the day).   If I can offer a few areas of improvement, it's the following: - Instead of having prohibitory signs on areas you can't go, add like, an accident, or road work, detour signs, etc or something more realistic as the floating signs make it more like NFS and take away immersion.  - Allow changing the GPS colours in options. I'm partially colour blind and green arrow on yellow road intersection was next to impossible for me to see at distance. Had to create/pack a basic mod editing the cfg file just to make it usable.  - In truck cabin sounds are much too quiet, I couldn't even hear the traffic. See above, had to pack a basic mod.  - During the tutorial make mention of the difference between POSTED speed limit and the truck speed limit (shown on the GPS). I'm not from Europe so wasn't aware of these regs and had to look it up thinking my GPS was broken. - More varied traffic vehicles like Fire trucks, Ambulances, Police cars. You added buses which is cool! - Would prefer ALL the DLC in the deluxe pack, even if it means replacing an older game included or an Ultimate edition as I'll personally probably never play the first ETS and would have preferred the added paint jobs and cabin interiors.  Those are literally me nitpicking to make the review more balanced, if you aren't convinced play the demo.

The second time, I was determined but it still took me 3 hours. My first mission took 3 hours to complete because I was bent on parking the damn trailer. Fantastic graphics, great sounds, very nice interface 9/10 but holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ the parking in this game convinced me to have my head looked at.

Well Euro Truck Simulator 2 (ETS 2 for short) has no storyline , untill you make one. No certain jobs to do, untill you choose one and unlike most games you start with almost nothing (you get some money from doing tutorial). It really does feel like you are running your own truck company, that is when you get the money. for the size of the world it is amazing that there are no parts that you need to wait as your driving like in oblivion in the wild it says loading area and in farming truck simulator when you want to drive into town its a 2 minute wait, ETS 2 is just smooth driving all the way around. The bugs on ETS 2 are decreasing and after 5 hours of playing i havn't encountered 1 bug. Small additions in ETS 2 make the game beautiful and there a lot in ETS 2 like the spray of water when other cars drive in rain, the aeroplanes lifting of from places that have an airport, and the many mods that can make it snow, custom cars, custom trailers and new cab designs. Although some people arn't really too keen on simulators i encourage all to atleast download the free demo to see what its like.  London to Paris. Paris to Amsterdam. Amsterdam to Sheffield.  Growing your business every step of the way. Overall Rating 9/10

Glad to have bought this game, can always come back to it when I want to relax or to play multiplayer with a friend.  Pros - Very Fun & Relaxing (If your not speeding) - Has third party multiplayer support (truckersMP, but beware if your in Australia or NZ there are no servers for us. The best you can get is hong kong but no one plays on that server, so you will most likely be on europe 2 in which you ping will be 200-250 (IF YOU HAVE NBN TO YOUR HOME) If you have ADSL then you will be stuck on about 300 ping. - Has a good variety of truck branding.  - Map is fairly large - Has decent graphics & is well optimised for lower end PC's - Has great wheel support & sounds.  Cons - Can be repetitive and you feel as if you have been to an area even if you havent been there before as alot of the textures such as the tress and grass are used alot. It seems most areas have the same city styling and country road styling. - AI isnt exactly amazing but it isnt the worst I have seen.   Overall a really good game especially if you have another friend or 2 to play with. If you have a steering wheel with a shifter and a few dollars to spare, wait for this game to go on sale and get it!   9/10 Would purchase again

I must say, this game has amazing graphics, and it's very fun. I highly recommend it.  Now, let's get to the entertaining part  I purchased this game a while ago. Here's my story:  -Installed game. -Made a new profile -Looked for the goofiest looking person -Chose a Volvo, because it's the only company that I recognize from North America -Chose the Fire company symbol, because I wanted my company to be hot -Got in game -Had to drive to a destination -After twenty minutes of trying to park, I skipped it -Finished first trip  -Took a quick job -Tipped when trying to get onto the freeway on the round connecting thing (What's that called again?) -Respawned back in Rotterdam -Happened again -Quit the job, took a fine -Quit the profile, time for a new one  This is how my Euro Truck life went for four or five more profiles. I finally found multiplayer, and decided I could stick to one profile  -Almost got banned for being a bad driver. -Played on Multiplayer for a while with friends, becoming a better driver. -Rammed my driving buddy into a wall. He was threatning to take my lane, and I stood up to him. -Haven't played with him since.  After this, I decided it was time for DLC.   -Went to Scandinavia -Was impressed with new textures, scenery and more -After several hours of gameplay with the DLC, I decided I should write a review  This has been my ETS 2 life, I really enjoy this game, it's a blast, but very relaxing. If I had a choice of this and American Truck Simulator, I'd choose this. It's just got more things to do, for now.

Graphics: This game is quite pretty. Nothing spectacular or mind-blowing, but there are moments when you have to balance driving and admiring the scenery without smashing into anything. There are also a few mods that can enhance your experience in this regard.  Audio: The music is pretty standard, but all of the other audio in the game is fantastic. The sounds of the vehicles are very realistic, especially since they have been updated over time. There are videos on the SCS website of how they record the engine noises, and it's very well done.  Gameplay: This is a very relaxing game. Not exciting by any means, but it can be quite satisfying to see your progress over time, and the driving can be enjoyable on its own. The progression itself is quite good. As you earn money, you'll be able to purchase other trucks for your company and hire drivers to operate them while you are on your own job to create additional revenue. You begin to snowball, and you eventually reach the point where money is no longer a concern, but that takes a considerable amount of time. You also earn XP, unlocking the ability to take more jobs. There is a decent variety of trucks in the base game to keep your interest, and this is one of those games that has an absolutely massive modding potential. There is a load of trucks, cargo, maps, truck parts, and more available to download to keep the game fresh. And don't let the DLC turn you away, as the majority of it is paint packs, which aren't necessary by any means. The other DLC, such as the Going East expansion, are superb.  TL;DR: This isn't really a game for everyone, but if you have interest, I do recommend picking it up on sale. It's a high-quality simulator, and it's very satisfying to progress in. Overall a great game to play to relax or chill while watching a video or listening to some music.

I am not particularly interested in Simulator games, and I haven't played one in 10 years. I got a sudden craving to, and I bought ETS 1 on sale, and I loved it. Lo and behold, ETS 2 goes on sale a week later, so of course I purchased it, and WOW. The difference is astonishing. Graphics, detail, variety, sounds, available jobs/missions, HUD (rearview mirrors, GPS, etc), and not to mention MUSIC. Yes this game has a radio that doesn't require you to manually put music into the game folder, but rather it streams music from the internet and there are a bunch of different stations to choose from. Plus, in this game, you can make your own company, have your own garage, hire drivers, and all that which is awesome. The driving and parking trailers in this game is more difficult than in the original, because it has more realistic physics, but that doesn't bother me much. It motivates me to get better. Anyway, BUY IT NOW while it's on sale for $9! Absolutely recommend.  PS. Oh, and I can't forget to mention, the modding scene for this game is amazing.

Euro Truck Simulator 2;  As you can tell from the name, it's a simulator. Let's just start this review off by saying, simulators are not for everyone. In Euro Truck Simulator 2 you take the wheel of a tractor trailer across Europe. You start your own trucking company and make deliveries. As you progress the distance gets longer and the money you make increases. Honestly, this is one of the best simulator games around. It's a great way to just sit back, relax and pass the time peacefully. Nobody is yelling at eachother like in multiplayer games. The only thing you have to worry about is keeping your truck in its lane, not hitting other cars/trucks and stopping for red lights. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves driving games and who maybe looking to get into simulators.  Pros: -Great Time Passer -Good Graphics -Very Realistic -You Drive All Across Europe -Learn How to Manage Your Own Company  Cons: -There is none, buy this game.  Final Verdict: 10/10  da!

I never thought I'd say this, but this game is actually really good. When I first saw it available, I thought 'You're kidding, right? How boring!' But I got it really cheap on a Steam sale and finally decided to try it out.  You drive a truck. That's it. At least, that's all I've done up to this point. But I'll be damned if it isn't amazing to look at. This game it superbly polished. The European countryside is beautiful to drive through; and when you add a real-world, streaming radio station on top of that, it's even more fun to drive around. I won't deny that I've decided to play 'one more job' just because a song that I love came on.  What's even better is that this game looks *gorgeous* in stereoscopic 3D. The truck cabin really comes to life; the mirrors float in space; the trees and buildings in the distance look like they're really in the distance! If you have an NVIDIA card, I really do recommend playing it in 3D. And if you connect it to a 3D TV (like I do), that's even better!  I haven't gotten to the point of getting a loan or starting a business. I don't know if I want to get into that kind of micromanagement.   But when I need some down time from the real world, I now have no problems hopping into a big 18-wheeler while listening to a European radio station, which came as a very pleasant surprise to me. And, yes, being a Yankee I am probalby going to get American Truck Simulator as well, which is something I never thought I'd say.

I didn't want to apply a thumbs-down because this is a game that achieves a fair bit of what it set out to do, and is obviously a labour of love. Nice day/night changes, a peaceful feel to it, a chance to listen to MP3s in a fairly stress-free game, comfortable controls. It took me a while to get it set up, but I was soon chugging up hills at 15 mph.  I think my main disappointment was to do with expectations. The blurb says: 'dozens of cities to explore'. I didn't expect 1-to-1 fidelity, but to me, explore means at least they would feel like cities, and be vaguely recognisable. Much as I'd have loved it to be like driving through Google Street View, I had already scaled back my expectations. I assumed maybe cities would only have a third of the roads, something like that. I wasn't prepared for reaching Cardiff, a city I know well, and discovering that it seemed to be two roads and a depot. Likewise with Swansea. Ouch. I'd persuaded my girlfriend that we might be able to drive from our hometown across Wales, then on to Europe, and eventually down the coast of Italy, perhaps finding the town where some of our family live. Wrong. The vast majority of places in each country are missing. A few cities will exists as just a couple of roads, nothing like what you'd expect from Saints Row/GTA/Sleeping Dogs. Don't get me wrong, that would be great but I understand why things have been scaled down - I just think it's deceptive not to make that clear from the sales blurb. If that had stated that there were 40 urban areas out of the many thousands, and that cities were scaled down 1,000 times, and that places with populations of below a million weren't included, I'd have at least had an idea of how far the game is from reality. For example, the UK alone has 69 cities (and many thousands of towns and villages) but ETS2 only has 18, each of which is a few roads. Cities mainly act as just blobs on a map, connecting points. A grand tour of Europe this is not - it's a patchwork quilt edged by invisible walls (well, you can see them, big Xs and chevrons floating in the air to stop you heading towards landmarks or B-roads or anything that isn't a motorway). The map of Italy seemed to cut off at the very edge - so technically Italy is included, but only as a few clumps of road in a teeny area. It seems disingenuous. Most European countries don't seem to be in the game. This is a disappointment only because of the misleading advertising.  It seems you can listen to radio stations in game but I never got that to work, no matter how many URLs I added to a text document nested far down my hard drive hierarchy. No error messages - good luck if you aren't IT literate.  Finally, I think I'd have got a bit more pleasure from it if I could have also had the option of driving around in a car rather than a truck. It's weird that the game simulates many things; as a company owner you probably have a car, but there is no option to go anywhere in it. I'd have thought a free drive mode would have been a nice addition for people like me, who don't want a racing game, just something more sedate, but the chance to explore the small part of Europe that has been included at a bit more of a zippy pace. Still, that's a suggestion, not a criticism. The main feeling I had was one of disappointment at the scale of the game. It may be hundreds of miles wide, but the detail is only inches deep, a surface impression that didn't really satisfy me. I can see why others might be happy with it. Maybe a more accurate blurb would have helped, rather than trying to sell the Earth.  ---  I can't comment on my own review's comments thread due to some error (thanks Steam), so here's my response to the comment by HaddockA, who said 'You're seriously crazy to even think that such a game in 2016 could even exist... That's like having GTA V multiplied by a factor of 1,000.... you're seriously weird. .'  My reply: 'I probably am crazy but that's a separate issue. Having never played one of these games, but having used the free Google Street view which lets you do something similar, I don't see why it was crazy to imagine the game would map 33% of the roads, rather than 0.01% (or whatever the figure is). After all, it says 'cities to explore'. But you get there and there is nothing to explore. Just a few roads, one supermarket with an empty car park, and a background view you can't reach. If the blurb included what % of Europe's roads were included in the game then I'd be a fool to expect otherwise, but they don't include that information, thereby inviting inflated expectations.'

With game playability, realism and in-game management, I'm very pleased.  It's fun to drive, fun to deliver the goods on time, take the money, invest in better trucks and bigger garages... plenty of fun moments to deal with.  But, if you find ETS2 world rather narrow (especially if you read the title 'Euro...' and put some effort to find good mods with wider map coverage or some truck equipment mods, you can end up (as I had) with complete career loss.  When the game updates itself (and you can't do nothing about that), there's pretty high possibility that mods will not be compatible with that new version. This phenomenon is not problematic by itself. It's acceptable to some point, because mods are created by people not related to SCS and their mods behaviour isn't something that SCS should deal with. We can discuss if the editor should allow incompatibility issues with minor updates, but this is something for separate topic.  BUT, if the game itself allows you to install mods, it should allow you to fix old savegames (profiles) so you don't lose everything you gained so far, just because new game version can't work with old mod and at the same time. So, when new version can't work with old mod, it's not the worst one - you can't load old savegame at all, because game warns you that your savegame contains some data which depending on these very mods, so you're on your own. You can play it from scratch or to give up for good, as you have no option to postpone update or downgrade if something goes wrong.  I just can't understand why SCS is unable to offer savegame update or at least clound profile data with we can import in freshly created savegame, to continue where we stopped?  OK, I'm ready to lose my beloved mods, wider coverage and better equipment, but some of them are stock and should be working.  So, I'm sorry, but this is a big dealbreaker for me.

Why I don't recommend this game? The reasons are many but the main is the game doesn't feel at all like truck simulator and the game is not challenging at all.  1. Lack of police - as much as we don't like them lurcking behind some bush IRL, the cops are absolutely necessary in this game. I was so disappointed when I found out there is no police on the roads. This kills like the half of the realism. You can drive with top speed on the highway without worring you can be pulled over for speeding, driving on shoulder or wrong lane or whatever. There are only few speed cameras and if you don't see the signs and get a ticked you can just quick load the quick save you made like 5 seconds ago and everything will be fine. Which leads to my number 2 reason.  2. Quick Saves - this option should not exist while driving. You can make quick saves every 5 seconds and if anything bad happens like get ticket, crash, miss exit or whatever you are just one quick load away. This is an exploit that can kill the joy of every player. Some of you will say 'then just don't use it' ... well there is one very bad human trait - temptation. When you know it is there sometimes you can't resist. You should be able to sava game while you are on the road only on resting areas.  3. Lack of routes - in this game there are onle highways and main roads. There is lack of options where you can choose to take different highways / IRL sometimes you prefer to travel longer but cheaper/. 3.1 - You can't choose to take a 'risky' route which can be shortcuts but it have restrictions for trucks and get pulled by cops and get a ticket /which leads to number 1./ or be stuck in low bridge which IRL can happen very often if you haven't checked the route before. There are no unknow roads that you can take the risk and explore.  4. No traffic jams near or in cities - this is one of every driver's /truck or car driver/ nightmare. To be on the wrong Highway at the wrong time of the day ... and be late for the delivery. Cities are very simply made in this game, and they look almost all the same, no matter if you are in France or Poland. No real traaffic experience. And even if you get 'stuck' on red light intersection you can just 'quick load' and all the traffic is gone! Wow .. magic!  5. Who gives a crap about signals and that kind of stull, right?  Maybe it sounds like hate, but this is my honest oppinion about the game. I had very big expectations because of the rating it has, but in my scale this game deserves no more than 5 out of 10. It needs more challenge, it needs more realism

Yes this game cost less than a gallon of gas, so how upset can I be? Reading the other reviews and seeing that this game has an 'Overwhelming Positive Response', I jumped on the sale price. I enjoy driving games and thought this would add a nice sim/management complexity to the typical 'racing' game. First off I don't think this is meant for anyone that doesn't have a full blown steering wheel/dashboard setup. There are way too many options to fully enjoy this game with a typical controller and driving games definitely lose something with a keyboard. It reminds me of something I learned when I got my game design degree, it was a Design class about how you really need to pay attention to the user interaction aspect of your design; to do that you need users to test and give feedback. A few examples of what I mean, if you have a game controller selected or a steering wheel, the menus should default to the selectable options only, no reason I should have to control a mouse pointer or at least give me a back/close button so I don't have to move the pointer all over the screen. The number of buttons it takes to really feel like you are driving is crazy in this game: Gas, Brake, Steering, POV, Turn Signals, Light, Camera View, Menu, wipers, etc. Not to mention setting these up on a controller, first you go into the control to set the steering, POV, Gas, Brake and Shifting. Then you have to go into the Keyboard menu to set the other functions. Why? It makes zero sense to have a Controller Menu but make me go into the keyboard menu to set it up. Ok, so let's say you can overlook that, it seems petty (and it probably is if this didn't have 2 in the title.) Now I agree with the majority when it comes to game play, there is something relaxing about loading up a couple hours of music and driving, while building an empire. But again, I have at least one major issue, the second freight job I took, when I was backing up to line up with the trailer, I misjudged and hit it instead. It proceeded to tip over, now the only option I have is to forfeit that job and loose $12,000. Although I can't verify this since I can't attach the trailer, but I suspect the trailer damage doesn't start to register till it is hooked up to the truck. If that is the case, why would they not incorporate some functionality to the trailer that it stays up right until attached (a switch built into the Unreal Engine, so it is possible). Now this also could be explained away possibly as realism, but part of the design process in anything is to manage the user’s frustration levels. Something like this could be handled like all other accidents I've had so far, a deduction in the total earnings. I sustained damage to my truck and I will lose almost all my money. Even in real life I would be able to call someone to flip the trailer over, but in the game it sunk into the ground. All in all, if you are looking for a few hours of relaxation, and you don't mind a few minutes of frustration and stumbling around trying to configure the game so you can play it, go for it. If you are looking for an improved sequel, this may not be it (although not having played the first, I can't say it's not improved.) I will reiterate, if this game was not a sequel I probably would have a totally different opinion, but the fact that the start of the game (set up and initial game play) are so frustrating, I tend to believe the entire game is riddled with this kind of stuff.  To the design team: make sure the player can jump in and control the game with minimal effort; first impressions are paramount.

I would say this 'game' is first- nicely produced, second- only a fair simulator of truck driving, third- has a large amount of places that are not accurate representations, and fourth- a large collection of customizations for your truck (like paint jobs).   One of the main reasons that prevented me from enjoying this game was the steering:  Steering the truck does not have a realistic feel to it. The steering is not smooth (even when trying and making many different adjustments via the options screen). Steering required constant tweaking back and forth to keep the truck in the lanes and in no way did I ever feel like I was steering a real vehicle. Driving a real vehicle I don’t have to constantly keep ‘on top’ of my steering wheel like you do in this ‘game’. I never felt like I could ever relax like I do when driving on a real road trip.  Other factors for giving this game a thumbs down:  There was not a wide variety of roads; after a while the road design repeated types of roads I had already driven in other locations.  Even though there is a large amount of locations, the locations were not even close to true representations and the location design started repeating just like the roads.  For me, there are way more fun and enjoyable games out there than to waste time on this one.  Also, I wonder if a large portion of the favorable reviews for this game are fabricated in order to drive up profits; note the metacritic reviews average a good amount lower than the steam reviews.

If you're looking for a real driving simulator I cannot recommend this.  A truck driving simulator sort of!  The game does not provide any realistic simulation as far as driving goes. 90% of the dashboard does not work, trucks do not have real world physics. Driving is boring, because your truck drives like a toy, because there's no skill involved to do it. Truck has horn lights and turn signals, but they don't matter, the Ai don't see or hear them. There is no visual damage, dirt or tire wear.  The trailers/equipment you pull has no weight to them, you look in your rearview mirror and they are going all the road because there is no physics attributed to the trailers.  It rains but you cannot slide, and it doesn't change your driving. Rain on the windshield is the only thing that changes, there is no physics so your truck is not going to slide or slip. There is no snow.  Sound is laughable in the game, there's hardly any, trucks sound OK outside, but inside they are muffled too much. No city or freeway sounds, it's so bad there are several mod's for sound. As much as the developers keep recording they don't seem to get it right.  AI of course is stupid and their behavior will cause you to get in several accidents. Things you will notice right away, there are no police in Europe, or ambulances or fire trucks, in fact all of Europe only owns about five different cars. And no motorcycles. You can get tickets for speeding or running a red light, a little bell goes off in a popup that says you just paid for your infraction.  Your business, you're able to hire employees, who you will never see, you must purchase trucks for them. No reason for that company logo you'll never see your driver's trucks on the road.   There are mod's that help with some of the games shortcomings, unfortunately you have to go looking for them because for some reason the developer will not form a nexus for mod's even though the community has asked. Make sure your antivirus is up to date when you go mod's hunting.   A lot of people voted to green light this game, to bringing it mainstream because it had a lot of potential to be a real world truck simulator, but the developer has just just sat on it. He wants the game more assessable to the younger players but still wants to call it a simulator for some reason.  Good game for little kids, but not for someone looking for a real driving simulator.

Using the keyboard while in town is passable, but once you get up to speed on the highways it gets extreemly difficult to steer around corners as you can only do full turns to the left or right. Try driving your car sometimes where you can only turn your steering wheel sharply (don't really try this). Going around turns I kept losing control of the rig and going into the ditch as my two trailers behind me could keep violently swerve every time I would attempt one of my spilt second 90 degree turns using the keyboard.  So, as I said. The game does seem fun, but I would seriously not recommend the game unless you have an external means of steering.

So, this is called Euro Truck Simulator. If they removed the first part of the name and just called it 'Truck Simulator', this would be a decent game. Driving a truck is no action-game, and this part of the equation is handled well here. The 'Euro' part, though, is a complete bust. Yes, there are maps of Europe with the major cities in the right places, more or less, and there are even some famous buildings somewhere on the horizon to look at, but that doesn't make up for the complete mess that the rest of the map is. Not even the major highways are in any way like they are in reality. I understand that they had to shrink the map to fit the game, and there is nothing wrong about that. I wouldn't want to sit there for 3 hours driving a truck from Frankfurt to Cologne. But even the shrinking should have allowed them to at least keep the proper relations and connections between the major highways, and they just didn't. I drove through areas where I know the highways really well, and except for the right numbers there was nothing that looked at all familiar. Really, once you're on the highway, everything looks like a mostly randomly generated landscape with very generic and sometimes completely unfitting regional tints. On top of that, the roads have a very simple structure that repeats over and over, so there's really nothing to do than listening to the radio... which is nicely done in the game.  You can buy this if you want a Truck Simulator, but don't expect anything from the 'Euro' part.
